Dialogue:
[doctor] . next patient is michelle king . date of birth : 05/07/1982 . please use toc template . she was admitted to district regional hospital on 06/29/2021 , and was discharged on 07/02/2021 . the patient is a 39-year-old female with history of quadriplegia due to , uh , prior spinal cord injury . she was experiencing increasing concerns for spasms and lightheadedness , significant constipation , and reported diaphoresis . she was evaluated in the emergency department where she was , uh , febrile and had significantly elevated white blood cell count of 23,000 . there were concerns for ongoing urinary tract infection , but she was treated with iv antibiotic therapy . she had labile blood pressure , headache , and vomiting . in the end , she slowly improved . she does have a supra-pubic catheter . cultures were obtained and reviewed . she was eventually discharged after clinical improvement of her symptoms . she presents today to follow up regarding these concerns . hi , michelle . how are you doing ?
[patient] not too bad . and yourself ?
[doctor] i'm good , thanks . so , it looks like you had an infection , right ?
[patient] yeah . but you know , i really do n't think it was a uti .
[doctor] okay .
[patient] i told them when i went to the er ... is that your phone ?
[doctor] it is , yeah . it listens to you and me and it does all of my documentation . it's pretty good stuff . um , tell me what's going on .
[patient] it is , in my humble opinion , that i was just constipated and that was what was causing my blood pressure to be so high . and i hardly pooped when i was there . then when i got home i had a massive poop and i felt much better . i told them that when i was admitted , and they did x-rays and everything , but they said , " no , " as they did n't think that was n't ... that was it . but you know , i felt so much better when i got home and finally pooped .
[doctor] okay . um , and the white cell count was the only thing that i think they were kind of concerned about because it was a little high .
[patient] so i wondered if automatic dysreflexia can affect the white count ?
[doctor] typically , it does n't .
[patient] okay .
[doctor] but , i mean , when i looked at the urine cultures that they checked , the cultures are not very impressive .
[patient] yeah , that's what they said .
[doctor] and when i go back and look , sometimes your white count is just elevated a little bit , and last year it was normal , so ...
[patient] hm .
[doctor] but in saying that , you know , inflammation can do that . so , yeah , you could be backed up and inflamed .
[patient] yeah .
[doctor] uh , they did n't do a cat scan , they just did an x-ray . but you feel like you're back to your normal self now ?
[patient] yeah . i mean , i went in because i knew my blood pressure was out of control .
[doctor] mm-hmm .
[patient] it was giving me a headache and making me throw up . and i know , at that point , i'm at the loss of what i can do at home .
[doctor] yeah , it was good that you went in .
[patient] so i went in and they made me feel better , and then i went home , as you know .
[doctor] well , maybe that's all it was .
[patient] yeah .
[doctor] so you're doing good otherwise ?
[patient] yes , i am .
[doctor] good . let me take a quick listen to you .
[patient] okay .
[doctor] all right . go ahead and take a few deep breaths . and breathe normally . now take several deep breaths . and two more . okay , good . you can relax . any pain or discomfort anywhere ?
[patient] nope .
[doctor] great . so here are my thoughts .
[patient] okay .
[doctor] you may recall it was extremely hot during that period leading up to you going to the hospital . i do n't know if you were inside for the most part ?
[patient] yeah , it was pretty hot , was n't it ? and i go out a bit , but i do tend to stay in more when it's hot .
[doctor] okay . well , if you do get dehydrated even just a little bit it can lead to further , um , or worsening constipation issues .
[patient] mm-hmm .
[doctor] i've had a lot of patients over the last couple of weeks coming in with just weird stuff , and i blame that a little bit on how hot and humid it was the last two weeks of june . so what i would do is wait a couple of weeks and then , if you could , come back in and we could do some , uh , complete blood work , uh , including your white blood cells and a full panel of cholesterol , since it's been a while .
[patient] okay .
[doctor] and it should normalize , but it's too soon to do it now . um , but maybe if i put some labs in you could come in in two to three weeks ?
[patient] sure , i can do that .
[doctor] great . so that appointment will let us kill a bird ... two birds with one stone since you're due to get blood work anyways for cholesterol .
[patient] okay .
[doctor] and then , i just wanted to make sure that the white count is okay , because if it remains elevated then that means there's something else going on with your bowels .
[patient] mm-hmm .
[doctor] i do n't think that's what we'll find , but we'll see .
[patient] i mean , i knew going in that i had n't had a regular bowel movement in a while , even though i drink the miralax every day .
[doctor] yeah .
[patient] when i do n't go , i double up on that .
[doctor] have i ever given you lactulose ? it would be a medicine you use in , um , conjunction with miralax . sort of a rescue type thing .
[patient] is that the stuff that comes in a bottle ?
[doctor] yes .
[patient] then , yes . i have it . it takes about two days to work and then it's a brutal two days .
[doctor] got it . yeah , it can be a little rough , but it works .
[patient] yeah .
[doctor] all right . so we have our plan . any questions ?
[patient] yeah , well , i would like to talk to you about covid , if we can .
[doctor] sure . so where are you at when it comes to the vaccine ?
[patient] i am unvaccinated .
[doctor] so what are your concerns about the vaccine ?
[patient] well , we do n't know the side effects .
[doctor] correct , we do n't .
[patient] it's too soon to tell the side effects , and i'm hearing more and more reports of people getting what's now termed as " vaccine injury " .
[doctor] right .
[patient] which i had never heard of before . i do n't know if it is a new term or not , but my take on the whole thing is that i'm young and healthy enough to beat it , even if my respiratory is limited . i also take a lot of vitamin c.
[doctor] okay .
[patient] i also take multivitamins and i'm closely monitored . so i guess i do n't feel as though i really the vaccine .
[doctor] well , my thoughts are that you actually should be vaccinated . i think you are high risk . if you get covid it's not going to be good for you .
[patient] okay .
[doctor] and i think it's safe . i mean , i understand and hear you . all of these stories out there about this , uh , regarding the vaccine . but i've seen all the bad things that could happen from covid . people have died in my practice , and i do n't disagree that if you got covid you'd probably be okay .
[patient] yeah .
[doctor] but i would consider you as someone that would make me a little bit concerned . i have had healthy people die from covid .
[patient] mm-hmm .
[doctor] i've had some people get really , really sick from it . so personally , i believe that this vaccine is completely safe . i really think that .
[patient] all of them ?
[doctor] yeah , i do , i do . i think there are side effects from all vaccines , so you have to go back and think about it . do you get flu shot every year ?
[patient] no , i do n't .
[doctor] right , well , it's hard for me to convince you because you're making a consistent viewpoint .
[patient] well , i am open-minded to this .
[doctor] mm-hmm . to me , it's , you know , a lot of the stuff out there is fear and most of us health providers have gotten the vaccine . we've seen what the virus can do . i also have gotten all of my kids vaccinated .
[patient] okay .
[doctor] so i'm not concerned about the side effects of this . i do n't think it does anything . um , and we have vaccinated 50 % of the country .
[patient] mm-hmm .
[doctor] the er is full of these vaccines .
[patient] i understand .
[doctor] so there are definitely potential side effects to the vaccine . i mean , there's guillain-barre , and all these things that could happen from the vaccine , but they're just very rare . my thing for you is i'm not convinced that there's alternative stuff or even the treatment we have , like the monoclonal antibodies , that will give help , but it's just my opinion .
[patient] well , that's what i'm here for .
[doctor] yeah . right now the numbers are low . even with the delta variant , when it starts mutating , it's actually good because it becomes more contagious , but less deadly .
[patient] okay .
[doctor] so that's what's gon na happen with covid . that's what's mo- most of the science supports and this is how most pandemics end , is that the virus starts losing its potency .
[patient] sure .
[doctor] but think about it , and if you have any more questions you can certainly let me know , okay ?
[patient] will do .
[doctor] all right . anything else we can discuss today ?
[patient] nope . i think i'm all set . thank you .
[doctor] you're welcome . so we'll see you in two to three weeks . have a good rest of your day .
[patient] thanks , you too .
[doctor] next line heading will be " acute to chronic constipation " . she believes her hospitalization was more likely due to her dysreflexia , from her quadriplegia that typically occurs . she did have a lot of vital signs changes , including blood pressure fluctuations . the patient feels like she has a good bowel regimen , including taking the miralax regularly as a primary treatment for constipation issues as well as lactulose for severe constipation . she feels like this was less likely a true urinary tract infection and was just related to her constipation . however , we did have a good discussion regarding her leukocytosis .
[doctor] i would recommend just in the next three or four weeks to come back in for some updated fasting labs , and we'll repeat the cbc just to make sure her white blood cells tend downward . uh , next line and heading will be " quadriplegia " . um , next line and heading will be " covid vaccine status " . again , she's hesitant . we had a good discussion , and i recommended that the only true preventative mechanism for covid is the vaccine . i do not believe that supplements are necessarily going to help stave this off . i would be concerned if she does n't get the vaccine and i would consider her at high risk based on her quadriplegia status . she does not want to get covid . however , she needs to make these decisions . she is somewhat homeopathic .

Note_1:
SUBJECTIVE
CHIEF COMPLAINT
Follow-up regarding recent hospitalization for infection.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS
The patient is a 39-year-old female with history of quadriplegia due to prior spinal cord injury who presented to the emergency department on ___ for concern of urinary tract infection. She experienced increasing concerns for spasms and lightheadedness, significant constipation, and reported diaphoresis. She was evaluated in the emergency department where she was found to have fever and elevated white blood cell count of 23,000. She received IV antibiotics and was subsequently discharged after clinical improvement of her symptoms. The patient returned to clinic today for follow-up regarding her concerns.

On examination, the patient is afebrile, hemodynamically stable, and alert and orientedx3. Her abdominal exam is benign without rebound or guarding. Her rectal tone is firm. Her neurological exam is intact except for left upper extremity weakness. Her cardiac exam is intact. Her pulmonary exam is intact. Her GU exam is intact.

The patient denies any change in her bowel movements. She states that she takes Miralax daily as a primary treatment for constipation issues and Lactulose for severe constipation. She believes that her hospitalization was more likely due to her dysreflexia from her quadriplegia rather than a true urinary tract infection. However, we had a good discussion regarding her leukocytosis.
Note_2:
SUBJECTIVE
CHIEF COMPLAINT
Follow-up regarding recent hospitalization for infection and constipation.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS
The patient is a pleasant 39-year-old female who presents for follow-up regarding her recent hospitalization for infection and constipation. She reports feeling fine except for occasional constipation. Her medical history includes quadriplegia due to a previous spinal cord injury.

She recounts that during her hospitalization, she experienced increased concerns for spasms and lightheadedness, significant constipation, and reported diaphoresis. She was evaluated in the emergency department where she was found to have a fever and elevated white blood cell count of 23,000. Laboratory studies revealed a leukocytosis and electrolyte abnormalities. She received IV antibiotics and underwent imaging studies. She was initially managed conservatively but later required admission due to continued complaints of constipation. During her hospitalization, she had a large bowel movement and felt much better.

On discharge, she was instructed to follow up with her primary care provider and return if her condition worsened. The patient agrees with this plan and denies any other concerns at this time.
Note_3:
SUBJECTIVE
CHIEF COMPLAINT
Follow-up regarding recent admission for urinary tract infection and possible constipation.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS
The patient is a pleasant 39-year-old female who presents for follow-up regarding her recent admission for urinary tract infection and possible constipation. She reports feeling generally well except for occasional constipation. The patient denies any fevers, chills, or other infectious symptoms. She was recently hospitalized for urinary tract infection and constipation. During that time, she experienced elevated white blood cell counts. She was started on IV antibiotics and underwent imaging studies, including X-rays and ultrasound. She was also given laxatives and stool softeners. Her constipation improved, and she was discharged home.

The patient notes that she has a Suprapubic Catheter (SPC) in place. This was placed by Urology. She uses it intermittently depending on her needs. She denies any problems with the SPC.

The patient has a history of quadriplegia due to a previous spinal cord injury. She experiences ongoing motor weakness and numbness below the level of injury. She uses a wheelchair for mobility. She also experiences frequent constipation and incontinence. She has tried various medications, including Miralax and Lactulose, to manage her constipation. These medications seem to help, but she still experiences occasional episodes of constipation.

The patient has received the COVID-19 vaccine. She states that she had some mild side effects, such as fatigue and headaches, following administration. However, she felt that the benefits of receiving the vaccine outweighed the risks.

The patient denies any personal or family history of autoimmune diseases. She denies any other medical problems.

Note_1:
ASSESSMENT AND PLAN: 
1. Quadriplegic with history of constipation, likely dysreflexia, and UTI.
Assessment: The patient is a quadriplegic with a history of constipation, likely dysreflexia, and UTI. She presented to the ED with fever, elevated WBC count, and headache. Her symptoms resolved with IV antibiotics and conservative management. Differential diagnosis includes constipation, UTI, and side effect of medication. 
Plan: 
- Continue lactulose for severe constipation. 
- Monitor vital signs and continue to address constipation. 
- Discuss COVID-19 vaccination with the patient and encourage her to receive the vaccine. 
2. Acute to chronic constipation. 
Assessment: The patient has a history of constipation and uses miralax regularly as a primary treatment for constipation issues as well as lactulose for severe constipation. However, she believes her hospitalization was more likely due to her dysreflexia, from her quadriplegia that typically occurs. She did have a lot of vital signs changes, including blood pressure fluctuations. 
Plan: 
- Encourage patient to take miralax regularly as a primary treatment for constipation issues as well as lactulose for severe constipation. 
- Consider referral to specialist for further evaluation and management. 
Follow-up instructions: 
- Return to clinic in 2 to 3 weeks for repeat CBC and assessment of constipation.
Note_2:
ASSESSMENT AND PLAN: 
1. Acute to Chronic Constipation 
Assessment: The patient presented with acute to chronic constipation. She believes her hospitalization was more likely due to her dysreflexia, from her quadriplegia that typically occurs. She did have a lot of vital sign changes, including blood pressure fluctuations. The patient feels like she has a good bowel regimen, including taking the miralax regularly as a primary treatment for constipation issues as well as lactulose for severe constipation. She feels like this was less likely a true urinary tract infection and was just related to her constipation. However, we did have a good discussion regarding her leukocytosis. Plan: 
- Continue current bowel regimen. 
- Consider adding additional medications if needed. 
- Follow up in 2 weeks to assess response to treatment. 
2. Leukocytosis 
Assessment: The patient has a persistent leukocytosis. This could be related to her constipation or other underlying conditions. Plan: 
- Obtain CBC to confirm leukocytosis. 
- If confirmed, order additional tests such as UA, CT abdomen/pelvis, or other appropriate studies to rule out other causes of leukocytosis. 
- Follow up in 2 weeks to assess response to treatment.
Note_3:
ASSESSMENT AND PLAN:
1. Constipation 
Assessment: Patient has a history of quadriplegia due to spinal cord injury, which causes dysreflexia and frequent constipation. She experienced significant constipation and was found to have a large colon mass on CT abdomen. She denies any recent change in bowel habits. Differential diagnoses include malignancy, inflammatory bowel disease, or functional constipation. 
Plan: 
- Will continue current bowel regimen, including Miralax daily and lactulose PRN. 
- If patient continues to experience constipation despite current treatment, will refer to colorectal surgery for further evaluation. 

2. Leukocytosis 
Assessment: The patient has a history of quadriplegia due to spinal cord injury, which causes dysreflexia and frequent constipation. She experienced significant constipation and was found to have a large colon mass on CT abdomen. She denies any recent change in bowel habits. Differential diagnoses include infection, inflammatory bowel disease, or functional constipation. 
Plan: 
- Will obtain CBC with differential and other appropriate studies. 
- If infection is suspected, will start empiric antibiotics. 
- If inflammatory bowel disease is suspected, will refer to gastroenterology for further evaluation. 
- If functional constipation is suspected, will increase dietary fiber intake and consider laxatives. 

3. Unvaccinated status against COVID-19 
Assessment: The patient is unvaccinated against COVID-19 despite being at high risk due to her quadriplegia. 
Plan: 
- Provide education about the risks and benefits of COVID-19 vaccination. 
- Encourage the patient to get vaccinated as soon as possible.

[doctor] hello mr. roberts , how are you doing today ?
[patient] i'm fine , thank you .
[doctor] good . good . so , i saw you were recently in the emergency room with high blood pressure and some palpitations .
[patient] yeah . that was back in march i think , but my girlfriend and i , we talked about it , and on that day i had a few cups of coffee , and no breakfast . so , i think it was probably more of a panic attack than anything else .

[patient] uh , no .

[patient] my new med is , uh , a combo med , something 40-25 .

[patient] uh , yes i am .

[patient] um , every day .
[doctor] awesome .
[patient] yeah . every morning , i take it when i get up , and it's been running at about , uh , 146 to 155 lately .

Note_1:
SUBJECTIVE
CHIEF COMPLAINT
Hypertension and palpitations.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS
The patient is a pleasant 49-year-old male who presents to the clinic for evaluation of hypertension and palpitations. He reports a history of hypertension since childhood, and states that his mother and several siblings also have high blood pressure. The patient's blood pressure has been difficult to control, despite multiple attempts at different medications. His current medication regimen includes Benicar HCT (hydrochlorothiazide-spironolactone) 40-25 mg Qday, Amlodipine 10 mg Qday, and Metoprolol succinate XL 25 mg Qday. He denies compliance with the DASH eating plan. The patient reports occasional episodes of panic attacks, which may contribute to his hypertension. He denies smoking, alcohol consumption, or illicit drug use. The patient reports regular walking on a treadmill, but not always. He denies any recent changes in vision, hearing, or headaches.

He takes a water pill every morning and monitors his blood pressure regularly. The patient states that his blood pressure has been ranging between 146 and 155 mmHg recently. He has not achieved the target of 120mmHg yet. He also notes feeling anxious and experiencing palpitations during episodes of high blood pressure.

label: ap
Note_1:
ASSESSMENT AND PLAN:
1. Hypertension 
Assessment: The patient has a history of hypertension, and is currently on three antihypertensive medications (amlodipine 10mg Qday, Benicar HCT 40-25mg Qday, and hydrochlorothiazide). He reports that his blood pressure is still elevated despite maximizing his medication doses. His potassium level is within normal limits. 
Plan: 
- Add spironolactone 25mg Qday to his current medication regime. 
- Monitor his potassium and sodium levels in two weeks. 
- If he is not controlled on spironolactone, refer him to the resistant hypertension clinic. 
Follow-up instructions: 
- Return to clinic in two weeks for monitoring of his potassium and sodium levels.
Note_2:
ASSESSMENT AND PLAN:
1. Resistant Hypertension
Assessment: The patient has persistent hypertension despite maximizing medical therapy, indicating resistance to treatment. He has a positive family history of hypertension and is at high risk for complications such as stroke and heart failure.
Plan:
- Will add spironolactone to his current antihypertensive regimen.
- Will obtain a metabolic panel and blood pressure check in 2 weeks to monitor electrolyte balance and blood pressure response.
- If not controlled on spironolactone, will refer to resistant hypertension clinic.
Follow-up instructions:
- Return to clinic in 2 weeks for follow-up blood pressure check and metabolic panel.
Note_3:
ASSESSMENT AND PLAN:
1. Hypertension
Assessment: The patient has a history of hypertension, with resistant hypertension despite maximized therapy with three medications. He is currently on Benicar HCT (Hydrochlorothiazide-Spironolactone) 40-25 mg Qday.
Plan:
- Add spironolactone 25mg Qday to current regimen.
- Monitor potassium and sodium levels in two weeks with a metabolic panel and blood pressure check.
- If not controlled on spironolactone, consider referring to the resistant hypertension clinic.

Follow-up instructions:
- Return to clinic in 2 weeks for lab work and BP check.

label: ap
Note_1:
ASSESSMENT AND PLAN: 
1. Lisfranc fracture of the right foot 
Assessment: The patient has right foot pain, bruising, and swelling following a fall onto her foot. X-ray shows subluxation of the base of the second metatarsal and a bony fragment in the lisfranc joint space. 
Plan: 
- Recommend surgery to correct the fracture and prevent complications. 
- Order MRI to further assess the fracture and ligament injuries. 
- Refer to physical therapy after surgery to improve strength and range of motion. 
2. Right hand dominance 
Assessment: The patient is right-handed and drives with her right hand. 
Plan: 
- Advise the patient to avoid driving until she is cleared by a doctor. 
3. Tennis elbow 
Assessment: The patient has a history of tennis elbow. 
Plan: 
- Continue to monitor the patient's symptoms and provide conservative treatment as needed.
Note_2:
ASSESSMENT AND PLAN:
1. Right foot pain, consistent with Lisfranc fracture 
Assessment: The patient presented with right foot pain following a fall onto the right foot during a tennis match. Physical exam revealed tenderness to palpation of the midfoot and positive piano key test of the first and second metatarsals. X-ray showed subtle dorsal displacement of the base of the second metatarsal with a 3 millimeter separation of the first and second metatarsal bases and the presence of a bony fragment in the lisfranc joint space. 
Plan: 
- Recommend surgery to place the bones in their proper positions using plates and screws to help prevent further complications. 
- Order MRI to further assess the fracture and any injury to the ligaments. 
- Patient will be in a cast and use crutches for 6-8 weeks post-operatively. 
- After surgery, patient will be referred to physical therapy to strengthen the muscles and prepare for return to sports.
Note_3:
ASSESSMENT AND PLAN:
1. Right foot pain consistent with Lisfranc fracture:
Assessment: The patient has right foot pain, bruising, swelling, and positive piano key test of the first and second metatarsals. X-ray shows subtle dorsal displacement of the base of the second metatarsal with a 3-millimeter separation of the first and second metatarsal bases and the presence of a bony fragment in the Lisfranc joint space.
Plan:
- Recommend surgery.
- Order MRI to further assess the fracture and any injury to the ligaments.
- Refer to physical therapy after surgery.
2. Tennis elbow:
Assessment: The patient reports right arm pain.
Plan:
- Recommend ice packs, heat wrap, and nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) as needed.
- Refer to physical therapy for exercises to improve range of motion and strength.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS 
The patient is a pleasant female who presents for follow-up after an interior STEMI. She reports she experienced similar symptoms similar to what she had during her previous heart attack, including chest pain and shortness of breath. She denies any recent chest pain or shortness of breath. She has been able to walk her dog every day for the past month, covering approximately 1.5 to 2 miles. She has noticed lower swelling in both legs. She takes ASA, Brilanta, Lipitor, Toprol XL, and Lisinopril. She has good insurance and is able to afford her medications. She has been managing her diabetes by watching her sugar levels and taking Metformin.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN: 
1. Right knee injury, likely ACL tear 
Assessment: The patient presents with right knee pain, swelling, and limited range of motion after a recent traumatic event. Physical exam reveals decreased terminal extension, terminal flexion, and positive Lachman sign, suggesting ACL tear. MRI will confirm the diagnosis.
Plan: 
- Order MRI of the right knee. 
- Start meloxicam 50mg Qday. 
- Instruct the patient to wear a knee immobilizer and use crutches when walking. 
- Limit activities, including sitting for long periods of time. 
- Slow down jogging until further evaluation. 
Follow-up instructions: 
- Return to clinic in 2 weeks for follow-up and review of MRI results.

Note_1:
ASSESSMENT AND PLAN: 
1. Right elbow pain secondary to medial epicondylitis 
Assessment: The patient presents with moderate tenderness at the medial epicondyle, pain with resisted pronation of the right forearm, and pain with flexion and bending of the wrist. Physical exam shows no discoloration, swelling, or bruising. Differential diagnosis includes tennis elbow, golfer's elbow, or cubital tunnel syndrome. 
Plan: 
- Rest the right arm in a sling for 2 weeks. 
- Apply ice to the right elbow for 20 minutes three times a day. 
- Take 600mg ibuprofen (3 pills) every 6 hours with food for 1 week. 
- Hold off on pottery for the next few weeks to allow the elbow to heal. 
2. Hypertension 
Assessment: The patient has a history of hypertension, currently well controlled with lisinopril 10 mg Qday. 
Plan: 
- Continue lisinopril 10 mg Qday. 
3. Diabetes 
Assessment: The patient has a history of diabetes, currently managed with metformin 500mg BID. 
Plan: 
- Continue metformin 500mg BID. 
Follow-up instructions: 
- Return to clinic in 2 weeks for follow-up.

label: ap
Note_1:
ASSESSMENT AND PLAN: 
1. Alcohol Use Disorder (AUD)
Assessment: Patient presents with a history of significant alcohol use disorder, currently drinking 4-5 days per week to excess. She reports wanting to stop drinking and has tried naltrexone in the past. She understands the benefits of stopping alcohol, including improvement in her hypertension, and agrees to start naltrexone therapy.
Plan: 
- Start naltrexone therapy on May 17th.
- Review side effects and risks of naltrexone.
- Discuss the importance of complete alcohol cessation and its benefits for her overall health.
- Recommend upgrade influenza vaccination and Shingrix.
2. Hypertension
Assessment: Blood pressure is elevated, 130/90 mmHg. Patient is taking lisinopril 10mg Qday and hydrochlorothiazide 12.5mg Qday. Her target blood pressure is 130-140/70-80 mmHg.
Plan: 
- Continue lisinopril 10mg Qday and hydrochlorothiazide 12.5mg Qday.
- Monitor blood pressure closely and adjust medications as needed.
Follow-up instructions:
- Return to clinic in 1 week for follow-up and discussion of progress.
Note_2:
ASSESSMENT AND PLAN:

Assessment: Patient reports frequent alcohol consumption, 4-5 days per week. She is motivated to quit and is willing to try naltrexone. 
Plan: 
- Will start naltrexone on May 17th. 
- Discussed risks and benefits of naltrexone, including nausea, headache, dizziness, anxiety, tiredness, and trouble sleeping. 
2. Hypertension 
Assessment: Blood pressure is currently well controlled. Target BP is 130-140/70-80. 
Plan: 
- Continue lisinopril 10mg Qday and hydrochlorothiazide 12.5mg Qday. 
3. Coronavirus Vaccine 
Assessment: Patient received COVID-19 vaccine on February 9th. 
Plan: 
- No further action needed. 
Follow-up instructions: 
- Return to clinic week of June 14th for second naltrexone injection. 
- Upgrade influenza vaccination and Shingrix.

Plan:
- Will initiate naltrexone therapy on May 17th.
- Discussed potential benefits of alcohol cessation, including improvement in hypertension, overall health, and risk reduction of various medical problems.
- Recommend support groups and counseling to aid in sobriety.

2. Hypertension
Assessment: Blood pressure is currently elevated (130-145/90-100). Patient is taking lisinopril 10mg Qday and hydrochlorothiazide 12.5mg Qday.
Plan:
- Continue lisinopril and hydrochlorothiazide.
- Adjust dosage as needed to achieve target blood pressure of 130-140/70-80.

3. Coronavirus Vaccination
Assessment: Patient received the coronavirus vaccine on February 9th.
Plan:
- Monitor for any adverse events associated with the vaccine.

Follow-up instructions:
- Return to clinic in 1 week (by May 14th) for follow-up and evaluation of response to treatment.
- If patient experiences any adverse effects or concerns regarding naltrexone, please call the office for further guidance.

Note_1:
SUBJECTIVE
CHIEF COMPLAINT
Annual checkup.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS
The patient is a pleasant 27-year-old female who presents for her annual checkup. She reports that she has been doing better, but struggles with her depression due to being trapped indoors and remotely for the past year. She denies suicidal ideation. The patient's depression has been managed with Prozac 20mg Qday, which she takes regularly. She feels that the medication has helped her in the past, and thinks that increasing the dose might help her through this current episode.

The patient also reports chronic back pain. She states that the pain is still present, but improves with movement. She experiences numbness in her legs, but no tingling or weakness. Her activities of daily living are not affected. She underwent CABG at the young age of 27 due to a congenital artery. She reports that her heart is doing well and her arteries are looking good.

Physical examination reveals no signs of distress. There is no thyromegaly. A 3/6 systolic ejection murmur is heard. Lung fields are clear. Abdominal exam is soft. Palpation of the lumbar spine elicits pain. Flexion of the back is decreased. Lower extremity strength is good. No edema is noted. ECG shows no changes from last year. Lumbar spine X-ray and back X-ray are stable from last year.

She also reports having chronic back pain that improves with movement and worsens with sitting. The patient denies numbness or tingling in her legs, weakness in her legs, or difficulty exercising or going to the store. She also denies edema in her lower extremities. Her heart murmur is stable and her ECG is unchanged from last year.

label: ap
Note_1:
ASSESSMENT AND PLAN:
1. Left MCL strain 
Assessment: The patient presents with left knee pain after falling while running with her niece. She has pain on the inside of the knee, especially with flexion and extension. There is no evidence of fracture or bone abnormality on X-ray. Her physical exam shows mild swelling and moderate range of motion. Differential diagnosis includes meniscal tear or ACL injury, although these are less likely given the absence of locking or catching sensations. 
Plan: 
- Will start Tramadol 50mg Q8H and Tylenol PRN for pain. 
- Will provide knee immobilizer and recommend ice three to four times a day for 20-30 minutes at a time. 
- Advised patient to avoid running for the next three weeks. 
Follow-up instructions: 
- Return to clinic in 2 weeks or sooner if symptoms worsen.
Note_2:
ASSESSMENT AND PLAN: 
1. MCL sprain of the left knee
Assessment: The patient presents with left knee pain after falling while running with her niece. Physical exam reveals swelling, pain on flexion and extension, and limited range of motion. X-ray of the left knee is normal. Differential diagnosis includes meniscal tear, ACL injury, or osteoarthritis.
Plan: 
- Will start Tramadol 50mg PO BID for pain management. 
- Will provide a knee immobilizer and instruct the patient to wear it for the next week. 
- Instruct the patient to ice the knee 3-4 times per day for 20-30 minutes each time. 
- Advise the patient to avoid running for the next 3 weeks to allow the knee to heal.
- If the patient feels worse or fails to improve within a few days, will consider further imaging such as an MRI.
Note_3:
ASSESSMENT AND PLAN: 
1. Left knee MCL strain 
Assessment: The patient presented with left knee pain after falling while playing with her niece. Physical exam revealed moderate range of motion, pain on flexion and extension, and positive pain with palpation over the medial aspect of the knee. X-ray showed no fracture or bony abnormality. Differential diagnosis includes meniscal tear, ACL sprain, or osteoarthritis. However, given the patient's history of trauma and physical exam findings, MCL strain is most likely. 
Plan: 
- Will start pain management with Tramadol 50mg BID and Tylenol PRN for breakthrough pain. 
- Will provide knee immobilizer, ice pack application, and elevation. 
- Recommend avoiding activities that exacerbate the condition for 3 weeks. 
- If symptoms worsen or failure to improve within a month, recommend follow-up with repeat imaging (MRI) and consideration of further treatment.

Dialogue:
[doctor] brittany edwards , 07 , 1898 . she is a return visit for ibs with functional abdominal pain , nausea , vomiting . ms. edwards is a pleasant , 32-year-old female who was last seen in august of 2019 with flares of abdominal pain , who was diagnosed with irritable bowl that was treated with bentyl .
[doctor] she had a previous prescription for reglan that she received from the emergency room that she used as needed for nausea . she was instructed to start a low dose fiber supplement , such as citrucel , daily , probiotics to help with gas and bloating , bentyl up to four times daily for intestinal cramping , and stop reglan and use zofran as needed . neuromodulators such as elavil and buspar were discussed but not started .
[doctor] hello , how are you ?
[patient] i'm okay .
[doctor] good . how have you been feeling ?
[patient] not so good .
[doctor] yeah , so my nurse told me you have been going out to eat some on friday nights and saturday nights and that you have had some spicy foods or spicy shrimp .
[patient] yeah , i have .
[doctor] okay . well , your gut probably does not always appreciate that .
[patient] no , it does n't like it at all .
[doctor] yeah , so ibs is one of those things where you are very sensitive to certain things such as spicy foods or fatty foods and alcohol . and this can cause lower belly stuff like cramps , or you can get upper belly stuff such as nausea .
[patient] i've been getting both .
[doctor] okay . um , so how frequently have you been getting or having a bowel movement on normal days ?
[patient] i'm starting to notice it's between two and three times a day .
[doctor] okay . and are they soft stools or formed stools ?
[patient] um , they're formed .
[doctor] okay . and after you have gone out either drinking with your friends , do you tend to have more diarrhea ?
[patient] yeah , i do .
[doctor] okay . do you feel it's the food or the alcohol or both ?
[patient] uh , well usually we go to friday's restaurant . i always eat pasta , the chicken alfredo .
[doctor] okay . i can s- i can bet it's the alfredo sauce .
[patient] but it normally does n't bother me .
[doctor] okay . well , pasta can make you bloated , uh , but it does n't usually cause diarrhea . grilled chi- uh , grilled chicken is usually all right . alfredo , though , is higher in fat , and it does contain dairy . but you're saying it usually does n't bother you ?
[patient] no .
[doctor] okay . what type of alcohol drink do you drink when you are there ? is it a sweet drink ?
[patient] most of the time it's either tequila or dark liquor . i prefer patron , but if i get brown liquor , i only get two . um , every now and again , i'll drink a martini .
[doctor] sometimes it's the mixer they tend to put in the drinks , but it can be a variety of things . um , so when you're not eating out or drinking , what we do on a daily basis does help keep us regular , so when it does flare up , it c- it might not be as bad . um , have you had any luck using the fiber like citrucel regularly ?
[patient] um , no . i guess i need to find a new drink .
[doctor] okay . and how is it during the week ?
[patient] like what i eat ?
[doctor] yeah , and with the diarrhea and abdomal- um , abdominal pain .
[patient] right now , i'm still having the cramping and sharp pains , so i've been avoiding heavy foods . i did have some fried chicken today , though .
[doctor] and was everything all right after that ?
[patient] yeah , for the most part .
[doctor] okay . remember , it's also the portion sizes . so i mean , if you eat a little and you feel fine , then that's okay . you have to just really watch the portions .
[patient] okay , good . i ca n't go out- go without some fried chicken at least once in a while .
[doctor] sounds good . all right , well let's take a look at you today , and we'll do a brief physical exam . you will hear me call out some findings . i will answer any questions , and we will discuss once we have finished the exam .
[patient] sounds good .
[doctor] all right . so the patient is alert and cooperative , appears stated age . all right . i'm going to listen to your heart and lungs . and lungs are clear to auscultation bilaterally . heart regular rate and rhythm . all right , so if you could just lay back for me , and i'll examine your abdomen .
[patient] okay .
[doctor] all right . do you have any tenderness ?
[patient] no , not really .
[doctor] okay . so the abdomen is soft , non-tender . no masses or organomegaly . and let me take a listen . normal active bowel sounds . all right . you can go ahead and sit up now . thank you .
[doctor] all right , so first i want you to try citrucel . it does come in a tablet . you should use it twice daily for regularity . then i would say , if you know you're going out and will possibly have diarrhea as a result , you can go ahead and use your bentyl 20 milligrams . you can do one tablet before you eat , and then repeat up to four times daily . and then on days when you feel good , you do n't have to use anything . um , and then on friday before you leave the house , you can take a bentyl and put one in your pocket for later , and then you can repeat the same thing on saturday if you want , and that will be totally fine .
[patient] okay , that sounds good .
[doctor] okay . and so your bentyl , that's the anti-spasm medication , and i would take the higher dose .
[patient] can i get a refill of that ?
[doctor] yes , absolutely . uh , so take one tablet about 30 to 45 minutes before leaving the house and then the second tablet at the restaurant . then with the nausea , um , i think we should try and see if you can recognize a pattern with what you are eating and drinking , um , um , about , like , what makes it worse .
[patient] yeah , i noticed i've been doing better with drinking water instead of sodas .
[doctor] okay , good . and then for your zofran , i would n't take that ahead of time . just plan on drinking plenty of water .
[patient] okay .
[doctor] okay , and you can take it , but before you do , we want to try to reduce the triggers . uh , so watch out for greasy or fatty foods and sugary drinks .
[patient] okay , i can do that .
[doctor] okay . and so , however , if it is not just these isolated inci- incidents and the symptoms are happening all the time , we could put you on a long term medication that would take ... that you would take every night . and so then you do n't have to use so much bentyl or the zofran . how do you feel about that ?
[patient] i was actually going to ask you about something like that to help avoid flares altogether .
[doctor] yeah , there is . and it actually works on the chemicals in your brain that are causing your gut to be overly sensitive . one is called elavil , but the only drawback is that it can make you a little sleepy . how does that sound ?
[patient] that sounds like a much better plan .
[doctor] okay , great . we can definitely do that . uh , just take it every night before bedtime .
[patient] okay , that sounds good . thank you so much .
[doctor] you're welcome . and so i have gone ahead and sent your prescriptions to your pharmacy . just give us a call if you have any questions or need us for anything else . and then let's plan on touching base through mychart email in about a month to just check in to see how you're doing with symptoms . okay ?
[patient] okay , that sounds good . thank you .
[doctor] you're welcome , and have a good rest of your day .
[doctor] so review of symptoms is positive for diarrhea , nausea , and abdominal pain . assessment and plan . brittany edwards is a pleasant female with ibs and functional abdominal pain , aggravated by high stress , poor eating habits , and poor sleeping habits . i've encouraged dietary and lifestyle modifications , as well as starting a neuromodulator such as elavil 25 milligrams at bedtime for ibs .
[doctor] she can use bentyl 20 milligrams as needed 30 to 45 minutes prior to eating out at a restaurant . she can also use zofran if needed . however , i have encouraged her to reduce greasy and fatty foods and alcohol consumption . i have asked her to follow up in one month by emailing over mychart regarding any side effects and issues , or issues with elavil or if adjustments are needed .
label: sub
Note_1:
SUBJECTIVE
CHIEF COMPLAINT
Irritable bowel syndrome (IBS) with functional abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS
The patient is a pleasant 32-year-old female who was last seen in August of 2019 with flares of abdominal pain. She was diagnosed with irritable bowel syndrome (IBS) and treated with Bentyl. The patient has a history of frequent IBS flares associated with spicy foods or fatty foods and alcohol. Her current symptoms include lower belly cramps, formed stools, and diarrhea after drinking alcohol. She prefers Patron, but sometimes drinks other types of liquor. She tries to avoid heavy foods, but occasionally eats fried chicken. The patient reports that Citrusel helps keep her regular, but she has not taken it consistently.
Note_2:
SUBJECTIVE
CHIEF COMPLAINT
Irritable Bowel Syndrome (IBS) with functional abdominal pain, nausea, and vomiting.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS
Brittany Edwards is a pleasant 32-year-old female who was last seen in August of 2019 with flares of abdominal pain, who was diagnosed with irritable bowel syndrome (IBS). She has a history of frequent episodes of diarrhea and abdominal pain associated with food intake, particularly with spicy foods and alcohol. She reports that her gut tends to react negatively to certain types of foods and alcohol. When she goes out to eat on Friday and Saturday nights, she typically consumes pasta dishes and grilled chicken. She prefers Patron margaritas, but occasionally drinks other sweet cocktails. She states that she feels bloated after consuming pasta, but it normally does not trouble her. She reported that she has tried Citrucel, but it has not helped. She has also tried Zofran, which helps with nausea, but it does not prevent diarrhea. She was advised to start taking Bentyl 20 mg 30 to 45 minutes prior to eating out at a restaurant. She can also take Zofran if needed. However, she was counseled to reduce greasy and fatty foods and alcohol consumption.
Note_3:
SUBJECTIVE
CHIEF COMPLAINT
Irritable bowel syndrome (IBS) with diarrhea, nausea, and abdominal pain.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS
The patient is a pleasant 32-year-old female who was last seen in August of 2019 with flares of abdominal pain, who was diagnosed with irritable bowel that was treated with Bentyl. She has a history of IBS with diarrhea, nausea, and abdominal pain. The patient reports that she has been experiencing worsening abdominal pain, nausea, and diarrhea. She attributes these symptoms to eating out at restaurants, consuming spicy foods and alcohol, and lack of exercise. She denies changes in appetite, fever, chills, or hematochezia.

She states that she uses Bentyl for abdominal pain relief and Zofran for nausea relief. However, she notes that these medications do not completely eliminate her symptoms. She states that she has tried reducing her alcohol consumption and increasing her water intake, which has helped alleviate her symptoms somewhat. She also notes that she has been taking Citrucel for regularity, but has not been consistent with its use.

Note_1:
ASSESSMENT AND PLAN:
1. Irritable Bowel Syndrome (IBS)
Assessment: The patient has a history of IBS, which is exacerbated by high stress, poor eating habits, and poor sleeping habits. She experiences diarrhea, nausea, and abdominal pain. Review of symptoms is positive for diarrhea, nausea, and abdominal pain. Assessment and plan:
Plan:
- Encourage dietary and lifestyle modifications.
- Start a neuromodulator such as elavil 25 milligrams at bedtime for IBS.
- Use bentyl 20 milligrams as needed 30 to 45 minutes prior to eating out at a restaurant.
- Use zofran if needed.
- Reduce greasy and fatty foods and alcohol consumption.
- Follow up in one month by emailing over MyChart regarding any side effects and issues, or issues with elavil or if adjustments are needed.
Note_2:
ASSESSMENT AND PLAN: 
1. IBS with functional abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting
Assessment: The patient has a history of IBS with functional abdominal pain, nausea, and vomiting. She reports worsening symptoms associated with high stress, poor eating habits, and poor sleeping habits. Physical examination reveals soft abdomen with non-tender tenderness.
Plan:
- Will continue current treatment with citrucel and bentyl as needed.
- Encourage dietary and lifestyle modifications.
- Consider adding neuromodulator such as elavil 25 mg at bedtime for IBS.
- Instruct patient to reduce greasy and fatty foods and alcohol consumption.
- Ask patient to follow up in one month via emailing over MyChart regarding any side effects and issues, or issues with elavil or if adjustments are needed.
Note_3:
ASSESSMENT AND PLAN:

1. IBS with functional abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting 
Assessment: The patient has a history of IBS with functional abdominal pain, nausea, and vomiting. She reports worsening of symptoms with high stress, poor eating habits, and poor sleeping habits. She has tried Reglan in the past, which helped, but she stopped taking it due to side effects. She has also tried Citrucel, which helps with constipation but not with diarrhea. She reports that she is able to tolerate small amounts of fried chicken without exacerbation of symptoms. Physical exam reveals soft, non-tender abdomen with normal bowel sounds.
Plan:
- Encourage dietary and lifestyle modifications, including reducing greasy and fatty foods and alcohol consumption.
- Start Bentyl 20 mg QID as needed for intestinal cramping.
- Start Zofran as needed for nausea.
- Consider neuromodulator such as Elvanil 25 mg QHS for IBS.
- Follow up in 1 month via email to check for side effects and issues with Elvanil or if adjustments are needed.

Headache.

The patient has a history of diabetes mellitus type 2 and takes Metformin 500mg Qday. She has not been monitoring her blood sugar levels recently due to stress. She has also been experiencing stress-related anxiety. She works long hours on the computer and does not take regular breaks.

The patient denies any recent trauma to the head or neck.

label: ap
Note_1:
ASSESSMENT AND PLAN:
1. Headache 
Assessment: Tension-type headache due to muscle tension in the neck and shoulders, possibly exacerbated by computer use and stress. No evidence of stroke or bleeding in the brain. 
Plan: 
- Continue Tylenol PRN for pain relief. 
- Start Flexeril 5mg QID for muscle relaxation. 
- Will obtain HbA1C, CBC, and Chem-10 to monitor diabetes and electrolytes. 
- Instruct patient to check her blood sugars daily. 
- If headache does not improve within a few days or becomes worse, instruct patient to return to the office or call for an earlier appointment. 

2. Diabetes Mellitus Type II 
Assessment: Patient reports poor compliance with blood sugar monitoring and exercise. Hemoglobin A1C is elevated (HgbA1C = 8.7%). 
Plan: 
- Continue Metformin 500mg BID. 
- Obtain lipid panel and fasting glucose to further evaluate diabetes management. 
- Set up follow-up appointment in 4 weeks. 

Follow-up instructions: 
- Return to the office in 4 weeks or sooner if symptoms worsen. 
- Check blood sugars daily. 
- Bring lab results to the follow-up appointment.
Note_2:
ASSESSMENT AND PLAN:
1. Headache
Assessment: Tension-type headache due to muscle tension and stress. No signs of meningeal irritation, stroke, or bleeding.
Plan:
- Continue Tylenol PRN for pain relief.
- Prescribe Flexeril 5mg QHS for muscle relaxation.
- Recommend regular exercise and stress management techniques.
- Will obtain CBC, Chem-10, and HbA1C to monitor blood sugar control and lipid profile.
2. Diabetes Mellitus Type II
Assessment: Patient has poorly controlled diabetes despite increased metformin dosage.
Plan:
- Continue Metformin 500mg BID.
- Order HbA1C, CBC, and Chem-10.
- Instruct patient to check blood glucose levels daily.
- Schedule follow-up in 4 weeks.
Note_3:
ASSESSMENT AND PLAN: 
1. Headache 
Assessment: Tension-type headache likely due to muscle tension and poor posture. No signs of stroke or neurological deficits. 
Plan: 
- Continue Tylenol for pain relief. 
- Flexeril 5mg tid PRN for muscle relaxation. 
- Encourage regular exercise and proper posture. 
- Return to clinic or call if symptoms worsen or fail to improve within a few days. 
2. Diabetes Mellitus Type 2 
Assessment: Hemoglobin A1C and CBC/Chem-12 were ordered. Patient is currently compliant with metformin 500mg BID, however, she reports poor dietary habits and lack of regular exercise. 
Plan: 
- Metformin 500mg BID continued. 
- Encourage regular exercise and healthy diet. 
- Follow-up in 4 weeks to reassess blood sugar control and adjust medications accordingly. 
Follow-up instructions: 
- Call clinic if symptoms worsen or fail to improve within a few days. 
- Bring hemoglobin A1C and CBC/Chem-12 results to follow-up appointment.

Note_1:
SUBJECTIVE
CHIEF COMPLAINT
Left arm pain.
HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS
The patient is a pleasant [age]-year-old male who presents to the clinic today for evaluation of left arm pain. The patient reports that the pain began approximately two weeks ago, when he woke up in the middle of the night with severe pain. He states that he lay some ice on the area and it eventually eased up. Since then, the patient has experienced recurrent episodes of left arm pain, occurring every few nights. The pain typically begins in the hand and travels down the entire arm. It is described as aching and throbbing in nature. The patient also reports weakness in his hand, making it difficult to grasp objects. He states that he has tried numbing medications, which provided some relief. The patient also reports history of neuropathy, which affects his legs and feet. He denied taking any blood thinners.

Since then, the patient has experienced recurrent episodes of left arm pain at night, occurring every few days. The pain typically begins around midnight and lasts until early morning. It is described as sharp, burning, and throbbing in nature. The patient also reports that he experiences weakness in his hand, particularly when gripping objects. This weakness is thought to be related to his neuropathy.

The patient denies any history of blood thinners. He takes Eliquis for cardiac health. He also takes gabapentin twice daily for left upper extremity neuropathy. His wife helps with his medications.

label: ap
Note_1:
ASSESSMENT AND PLAN: 
1. Left upper extremity neuropathy suspicious for cervical radicularopathy 
Assessment: The patient reports left arm pain, especially at night, which suggests a flare of cervical radiculopathy. He also has a history of neuropathy in his legs, which could contribute to his current symptoms. 
Plan: 
- Obtain MRI of the neck to assess the degree of disc degeneration and narrowing of the neural foramina. 
- Set up for a C7-T1 epidural injection, contingent upon the MRI results. 
- Continue twice daily gabapentin. 
- Recommend continuing home exercise program. 
2. Neck pain in the setting of arthritis disc degeneration 
Assessment: The patient has severe disc degeneration at C5-C6, C4-C5, and C3-C4 levels, suggestive of cervical spondylosis. This could be causing his neck pain. 
Plan: 
- Consider conservative management with physical therapy and medications. 
3. Peripheral neuropathy 
Assessment: The patient has a history of peripheral neuropathy in his legs, which could be contributing to his current symptoms. 
Plan: 
- Monitor for signs of progression of the neuropathy. 
- Refer to a specialist if necessary. 
Follow-up instructions: 
- Return to clinic in 1 week for follow-up.
Note_2:
ASSESSMENT AND PLAN:

1. Left upper extremity neuropathy suspicious for cervical radicularopathy, possible contribution of peripheral neuropathy.
Assessment: Patient presents with left upper extremity neuropathy, numbness, and weakness in the hand, consistent with cervical radiculopathy. X-ray shows significant disc degeneration at C5-C6 and C4-C5, which could explain the patient's symptoms. However, the patient also reports a history of peripheral neuropathy, which could contribute to the symptoms.
Plan:
- Will obtain MRI of the cervical spine to further assess the cause of the patient's symptoms.
- Will refer the patient to physical therapy for exercises to improve mobility and reduce pain.
- Continue gabapentin 300mg TID.

2. Neck pain in the setting of arthritis disc degeneration.
Assessment: Patient presents with neck pain in the setting of arthritis disc degeneration. X-ray shows significant lower lumbar facet arthropathy at C6-7 and C7-T1, which could be contributing to the patient's pain.
Plan:
- Will obtain MRI of the cervical spine to further assess the cause of the patient's symptoms.
- Recommend heat or cold packs to the area to relieve pain.
- Consider physical therapy or chiropractic care to improve mobility and reduce pain.

Follow-up instructions:
- Return to clinic in 2 weeks to discuss the results of the MRI and epidural injection.
Note_3:
ASSESSMENT AND PLAN: 

1. Left upper extremity neuropathy suspicious for cervical radicularopathy, possible contribution of peripheral neuropathy 
Assessment: The patient presented with left upper extremity neuropathy and neck pain in the setting of arthritis disc degeneration. His cervical X-ray revealed significant disc degeneration at C5-C6 and to a lower extent C4-C5 and C3-C4, and significant lower lumbar facet arthropathy C6-T1. 
Plan: 
- Will obtain MRI of the cervical spine to further evaluate the cause of his symptoms. 
- Will consider starting Gabapentin 300-600mg QHS for pain management. 
- Will refer the patient to physical therapy to improve mobility and strength. 

Follow-up instructions: 
- Return to clinic in 1 month for reassessment of symptoms and response to treatment.

label: ap
Note_1:
ASSESSMENT AND PLAN:
1. Anxiety 
Assessment: The patient reports improvement in her anxiety symptoms. She attributes this improvement to Buspirone, which was prescribed by Dr. Brown. However, she mentions that she experienced anxiety spikes at random times, especially prior to her menstruation. She also describes irritability and mood changes during the period leading up to her menstruation. These symptoms suggest possible premenstrual dysphoric disorder (PMDD).
Plan:
- Continue Buspirone.
- Consider starting Sertraline if symptoms persist.
2. Breast Lumps
Assessment: The patient reports persistent breast lumps despite being on Progesterone. The lumps are tender to palpation and have been present for several years. They may represent fibrocystic breast disease or breast cancer.
Plan:
- Monitor the lumps closely.
- Order a mammogram to rule out breast cancer.
3. Masked Face
Assessment: The patient reports losing weight over the past few months. Her appetite has increased significantly. She feels that her masked face is thinner. This suggests possible Cushing syndrome.
Plan:
- Repeat the Pap smear.
- Measure cortisol levels.
- Refer to endocrinology for further management.
4. Vaccine Hesitation
Assessment: The patient expresses hesitation regarding COVID-19 vaccination. She reports that her husband and daughter share similar concerns.
Plan:
- Provide education on the benefits of COVID-19 vaccination.
- Offer support and resources for vaccine administration.
Note_2:
ASSESSMENT AND PLAN:

1. Anxiety:
Assessment: Patient reports improvement of anxiety symptoms following initiation of Buspirone. However, she continues to experience anxiety prior to menstruation. She denies any other changes in mood, sleep, appetite, or energy levels. Physical examination reveals bilateral breast lumps, which may be related to hormonal fluctuations. 
Plan: 
- Continue Buspirone 5mg QHS. 
- Refer to Breast Specialist for further evaluation and management of breast lumps. 

2. Breast Lumps: 
Assessment: Bilateral breast lumps are stable in size and location compared to previous examinations. Differential diagnosis includes benign cysts, fibroadenomas, or early stage breast cancer. Physical examination and imaging studies are pending. 
Plan: 
- Follow up with Breast Specialist as scheduled. 
- Monitor for any changes in breast symptoms. 
- Consider diagnostic mammography if clinically indicated.
Note_3:
ASSESSMENT AND PLAN:

1. Anxiety
Assessment: The patient reports improved anxiety, likely due to starting Buspar. However, the patient continues to experience anxiety spikes without clear triggers. Differential diagnosis includes PMDD (as the patient's symptoms improve with menstruation) vs. hormonal changes from the progesterone.
Plan:
- Continue Buspar


2. Breast Lumps
Assessment: The patient has persistent bilateral breast lumps despite treatment with progesterone and Buspar. Differential diagnosis includes fibrocystic breast disease vs. malignancy.
Plan:
- Schedule follow-up appointment with breast specialist.
- Refill prescription for topical cream.
- Monitor breast lumps closely and consider additional testing if they fail to resolve over time.

3. Pap Smear Abnormality
Assessment: The patient has a history of abnormal Pap smear in 2009, followed by normal Pap smears until 2019. She is currently scheduled for a repeat Pap smear.
Plan:
- Schedule routine Pap smear.

Follow-up instructions:
- Return to clinic in 6 weeks for review of Pap smear results.

- Recommend reaching out to urology for a possible ultrasound.

Plan:
- Continue monitoring the patient's COVID-19 status.

- Return to clinic in one year for a wellness visit, sooner if needed.
- Call with any questions or concerns.

SUBJECTIVE
CHIEF COMPLAINT
Yearly examination.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS
The patient is a pleasant 24-year-old female who presents for her yearly examination. She reports having type 2 diabetes and high blood pressure. Her blood sugars have been up and down due to her diet. She has been resistant to the temptation of desserts while working at a bakery. She denies any problems with sleeping or self-harm.

Physical examination shows a grade 2 systolic ejection fraction back ejection murmur. Neurologically, she has equal strength in all muscle groups, including the abductors and adductors. There is no carotid bruits in the neck, thyromegaly, or edema. The lungs are clear, and the grip is equal.

LAB WORK
Hemoglobin A1C is elevated.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN
1. Diabetes
Assessment: Elevated hemoglobin A1C suggests poor blood glucose control.
Plan:
- Continue metformin twice daily.
- Encourage healthy diet and weight loss.
- Check blood sugars in the morning and report in about two weeks.
- Follow up in about two months.

2. Hypertension
Assessment: Blood pressure is currently well controlled.
Plan:
- Continue lisinopril 10 mg once a day.
- Monitor blood pressure regularly.

The patient is a pleasant [age]-year-old male who presents to the clinic today for evaluation of right hand numbness, tingling, and pain. He also reports pain in his hand when he uses his mouse. He takes ibuprofen for pain relief. The patient notes he experiences pain with flexion and extension of his right wrist. There is decreased grip strength on the right side compared to the left. He also experiences numbness in his thumb, index finger, and middle finger.

The doctor suspects carpal tunnel syndrome and plans to initiate conservative treatment with a wrist splint, ibuprofen, and nerve conduction studies.

Note_1:
ASSESSMENT AND PLAN: 
1. Carpal tunnel syndrome 
Assessment: The patient presents with right hand numbness, tingling, and pain, especially with typing on the keyboard and using the mouse. Physical exam reveals decreased grip strength and positive Tinel's sign. 
Plan: 
- Will place the patient in a wrist splint at night. 
- Continue ibuprofen at 600 mg Q4h. 
- Order EMG as an outpatient to evaluate nerve conduction study in the wrist. 
2. Pain management 
Assessment: Patient experiences pain with typing on the keyboard and using the mouse. 
Plan: 
- Continue ibuprofen as above. 
3. Follow-up instructions: 
- Return to clinic in 2 weeks for follow-up after EMG results are returned.
Note_2:
ASSESSMENT AND PLAN: 
1. Carpal tunnel syndrome 
Assessment: Patient presents with numbness, tingling, and pain in the right hand, particularly in the thumb and index finger, as well as in the middle finger. Physical exam reveals decreased grip strength on the right side and positive Tinel's sign. Differential diagnosis includes cubital tunnel syndrome, thoracic outlet syndrome, or cervical radiculopathy. However, given the location of the pain and numbness, carpal tunnel syndrome is the most likely diagnosis. 
Plan: 
- Will obtain EMG to confirm the diagnosis. 
- Will place the patient in a wrist splint at night. 
- Will increase the patient's ibuprofen dosage to 600mg QID. 
- If the EMG confirms carpal tunnel syndrome, will discuss surgical options. 
2. Pain control 
Assessment: The patient reports that ibuprofen and avoiding typing on the keyboard help relieve their pain. 
Plan: 
- Continue ibuprofen as above. 
3. Sleep disturbance 
Assessment: The patient denies any sleep disturbances. 
Plan: 
- No specific interventions needed.
Note_3:
ASSESSMENT AND PLAN: 
1. Carpal tunnel syndrome 
Assessment: Right hand numbness, tingling, and pain, with positive Tinel's sign. Patient has history of typing on computer keyboard for extended periods of time. No history of trauma. 
Plan: 
- Will place patient in a wrist splint at night. 
- Continue ibuprofen 600 mg QID. 
- Order EMG as outpatient. 
- If EMG comes back positive, will discuss surgical options. 
Follow-up instructions: 
- Return to clinic in 2 weeks for follow-up.

label: ap
Note_1:
ASSESSMENT AND PLAN: 
1. Neovascular age-related macular degeneration (wet macular degeneration) 
Assessment: The patient presents with decreased vision, particularly in low-light environments, and wavy appearance of straight lines. He also reports a history of smoking and hypertension. The diagnosis is confirmed by OCT and fluorescein angiography. 
Plan: 
- Will initiate monthly injections of Lucent. 
- Recommend quitting smoking and monitoring blood pressure. 
2. Hypertension 
Assessment: The patient reports difficulty controlling his blood pressure despite taking medication. His BP is currently elevated. 
Plan: 
- Repeat blood pressure measurement today. 
- Increase antihypertensive therapy if necessary. 
Follow-up instructions: 
- Return to clinic in 1 week for follow-up appointment.
Note_2:
ASSESSMENT AND PLAN: 
1. Neovascular age-related macular degeneration (wet AMD) 
Assessment: The patient has a history of smoking, hypertension, and decreased vision in the right eye. Examination revealed posterior chamber intraocular lenses in both eyes, drusen in the macula, retinal thickening, subretinal fluid accumulation, and hemorrhage in the right eye, and RPE changes in the fovea. Fluorescein angiography showed focal area of leakage in the right eye consistent with neurovascular AMD. 
Plan: 
- Will schedule the patient for regular follow-up appointments. 
- Will monitor blood pressure and provide education on quitting smoking. 
2. Hypertension 
Assessment: The patient has a history of hypertension and reports not taking his blood pressure medication for a while. 
Plan: 
- Will restart the patient's blood pressure medication. 
3. Smoking cessation 
Assessment: The patient has a history of smoking and reports difficulty quitting. 
Plan: 
- Will provide counseling on smoking cessation. 
Follow-up instructions: 
- Return to clinic in 4 weeks for evaluation of response to treatment.
Note_3:
ASSESSMENT AND PLAN: 
1. Neovascular Age-Related Macular Degeneration (wet AMD)
Assessment: The patient has bilateral vision changes, particularly in low light environments, and has been diagnosed with wet AMD. He has a history of smoking and hypertension.
Plan:
- Will perform fluorescein angiography to confirm the diagnosis.
- Will initiate treatment with Lucent once per month.
- Encourage smoking cessation.
- Recommend follow-up in 1 week for injection.
2. Hypertension
Assessment: The patient has a history of hypertension and reports not taking his blood pressure medication recently.
Plan:
- Will recommend restarting antihypertensive therapy.
3. Smoking Cessation
Assessment: The patient has a history of smoking and wants to quit.
Plan:
- Will provide counseling and resources for smoking cessation.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN: 
1. Upper respiratory tract infection (URTI) 
Assessment: Patient presents with a 3-day history of cough, which started gradually and is associated with mucus production. The patient also reports sore throat, nasal congestion, and low grade temperature. The patient denies shortness of breath, chest pain, or dyspnea. Physical exam shows bilateral maxillary sinus tenderness. Differential diagnosis includes viral syndrome, bacterial URTI, allergies, or asthma. 
Plan: 
- Continue supportive care with fluids, rest, and cough medications as needed. 
2. Type 2 diabetes 
Assessment: Patient has a history of type 2 diabetes. Her blood glucose levels have been well controlled recently. She takes metformin 500mg BID. 
Plan: 
- Continue metformin 500mg BID. 
- Check hemoglobin A1C at her next visit. 
3. Hypertension 
Assessment: Patient's blood pressure is currently elevated at 144/72 mmHg. She has been experiencing intermittent hypertension at home. She is currently taking hydrochlorothiazide 12.5mg Qday. 
Plan: 
- Increase hydrochlorothiazide to 25mg Qday. 
- Instruct patient to monitor her blood pressure regularly. 
Follow-up instructions: 
- Return to clinic in 1 week for follow-up.
Note_2:

Assessment: Patient presents with cough, green phlegm, sore throat, nasal congestion, and body aches. Differential diagnosis includes viral infection vs bacterial infection. 
Plan: 
- Continue supportive care with hydration, humidifier, and over-the-counter cough suppressants. 
- Check for COVID-19. 
2. Type 2 diabetes 
Assessment: Patient has a history of type 2 diabetes and is currently on metformin 500mg QHS. Her HbA1C was checked at her last visit and was within normal limits. 
Plan: 
- Continue metformin 500mg QHS. 
- Monitor blood glucose levels closely. 
3. Hypertension 
Assessment: Patient has a history of hypertension and is currently on hydrochlorothiazide 25mg PO QDay. Her blood pressure is elevated today, SBP 144/72. 
Plan: 
- Increase hydrochlorothiazide to 25mg PO QDay. 
- Recommend monitoring blood pressure regularly. 
Follow-up instructions: 
- Return to clinic in 1 week for follow-up appointment.
Note_3:
ASSESSMENT AND PLAN:

Assessment: Patient presents with a 3-day history of persistent cough, green sputum production, and increased sore throat. She also reports nasal congestion and a slight headache. She denies fever, shortness of breath, or body aches. Physical examination reveals bilateral maxillary sinus tenderness and anterior cervical adenopathy. Differential diagnosis includes viral URTI versus bacterial URTI. 
Plan: 
- Continue supportive care with plenty of fluid, saltine crackers, and cough suppressants.

2. Type 2 diabetes

Plan: 
- Continue metformin 500mg QHS. 
- Check HbA1C level at next visit.

She also denies any history of arthritis, inflammatory conditions, or prior surgeries. She notes that the pain is located behind her kneecaps and is described as deep achy. The pain is exacerbated by sitting for a prolonged period, getting up from a seated position, and climbing stairs. She works from home and spends most of her day sitting. She is an avid runner and runs approximately 5-6 miles per day, but her knee pain limits her to only running half a mile. She has tried ibuprofen, Aleve, and Tylenol for relief, but the pain still persists. Physical exam reveals tenderness to palpation and positive patellar grind test. X-rays of both knees were obtained and showed no fractures or osteoarthritis. Based on the patient's history and physical exam findings, the diagnosis is likely patellofemoral pain syndrome.

Note_1:
ASSESSMENT AND PLAN: 
1. Patellofemoral pain syndrome 
Assessment: The patient presents with left and right knee pain, particularly with squatting and climbing stairs. She has a history of patellofemoral pain syndrome and has tried various medications without relief. Physical exam reveals tenderness to palpation and positive patellar grind test. X-rays show no fractures or osteoarthritis. MRI showed patellofemoral joint degenerative changes. 
Plan: 
- Continue taking ibuprofen or Aleve as needed for pain relief. 
- Recommend physical therapy to improve lower extremity strength, mobility, and correct any incorrect running mechanics. 
2. Vitamin D deficiency 
Assessment: The patient has low vitamin D levels. 
Plan: 
- Start Vitamin D supplementation. 
Follow-up instructions: 
- Return to clinic in 6 weeks for follow-up.
Note_2:
ASSESSMENT AND PLAN: 
1. Patellofemoral pain syndrome 
Assessment: The patient presents with left and right knee pain, worse with squatting, sitting, and climbing stairs, and improved with rest. She also reports a history of overuse injury and has been using NSAIDs and Tylenol without relief. Physical exam reveals tenderness to palpation and positive patellar grind test. X-rays of both knees show no fractures or osteoarthritis. MRI showed patellofemoral joint degenerative changes. 
Plan: 
- Continue NSAIDs and Aleve as needed for pain. 
- Recommend physical therapy to improve lower extremity strength, mobility, and correct running mechanics. 
- Advise the patient to avoid activities that exacerbate her knee pain. 
2. Overtraining 
Assessment: The patient reports that she is a frequent runner who runs about 5-6 miles per day. However, due to her knee pain, she can only run about half a mile. 
Plan: 
- Encourage the patient to reduce her running distance to allow her knees to heal. 
3. Hypertension 
Assessment: The patient's blood pressure is well controlled at 120/70 mmHg. 
Plan: 
- Continue lisinopril 40mg Qday.
Note_3:
ASSESSMENT AND PLAN: 
1. Patellofemoral pain syndrome 
Assessment: The patient presents with left knee pain, which started approximately 6 months ago. She also reports right knee pain. She describes the pain as a deep achy pain that is exacerbated by sitting and standing up. Physical exam reveals tenderness to palpation and a positive patellar grind test. MRI showed no fracture or osteoarthritis. 
Plan: 
- Continue ibuprofen or Aleve as needed for pain relief. 
- Refer to physical therapy for lower extremity exercises and correction of running mechanics. 
- Encourage gentle exercise and avoid heavy impact activities such as running until pain improves. 
Follow-up instructions: 
- Return to clinic in 2 weeks or sooner if pain worsens.

Right hip pain.

The pain is worsened by movement, particularly pivoting. She denies any fevers or chills. She also denies any tingling or numbness. She has a history of multiple surgeries, including PCL, infertility, gallbladder removal, and several other unspecified procedures. She states that she has lost 110 pounds using Weight Watchers. Note_2:
SUBJECTIVE
CHIEF COMPLAINT
Right hip pain.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS
The patient is a pleasant 56-year-old female who presents to the clinic today for evaluation of right hip pain. The patient reports that her symptoms began in February 2020, and she initially experienced pain in the groin area. She states that the pain has worsened recently, and now it hurts whenever she moves. The patient rates the pain as 2-7 out of 10. She denies fever, chills, tingling, or numbness. She also denies any problems with her bowel or bladder.

The patient reports that she has had multiple surgeries, including PCL, infertility, gallbladder removal, and intentional weight loss. She has lost 110 pounds using Weight Watchers. She works at an infusion center and lives with a roommate. She limits alcohol intake to less than five drinks per month.

Physical exam reveals that the patient is five feet, six inches tall and weighs 169 pounds. Blood pressure is 115/75, pulse rate is 67. Ankles are intact, no ankle edema is noted, no calf tenderness. Examination of the cervical spine shows no pain, no tenderness. Range of motion is full in the neck without pain. Spurling's test is negative. Examination of the low back shows no pain, skin is intact, no midline tenderness to palpitation. Lateral flexion without pain. Resisted right hip flexion causes pain in the right groin region. No tenderness is noted. Motor control is normal in the lower extremities. Lift knee up, no pain. Squeeze knees together, push it out and kick your leg out straight, bring it back and kick it out straight again. Lean back, keep it loose.

MRI arthrogram of the right hip done on June 3rd, 2021, shows high-grade condromalacia involving the interosuperior right acetabulum with subchondral marrow edema and cyst formation.

Right hip pain.

The patient is a pleasant 56-year-old female who presents to the clinic today for evaluation of right hip pain. The patient reports the pain began in February 2020 and is located in the groin area. She describes the pain as being sharp and stabbing, and it is worse with movement. She denies fevers, chills, tingling, or numbness. She rates the pain as 2-7 out of 10. ASSESSMENT AND PLAN:
1. Right hip degenerative joint disease
Assessment: The patient presents with right hip pain, limited range of motion, and positive resisted right hip flexion causing pain in the right groin region. Physical exam reveals decreased range of motion in the right hip with pain in the groin and internal and external rotation. Motor control is normal in the lower extremities.
Plan:
- Start low impact exercises.
- Take NSAIDs as needed to help with pain and discomfort.
- Use a cane to offload the right side.
- Consider cortisone injection into the right hip joint.
Follow-up instructions:
- Follow up with Dr. ___ in 3 months for another injection if needed.
Note_2:
ASSESSMENT AND PLAN: 

1. Right hip degenerative joint disease
Assessment: The patient presents with right hip pain, limited range of motion, and positive resistance testing. Physical exam findings suggestive of right hip degenerative joint disease. Radiographs and MR arthrogram of the right hip confirm the diagnosis.
Plan: 
- Start low impact exercises to improve symptoms.
- Use NSAIDs as needed to help with pain and inflammation.
- Use a cane to offload the right side and reduce pain.
- Consider cortisone injection into the right hip joint.
- Follow up in 3 months to assess response to treatment and consider additional cortisone injection if necessary.
Note_3:
ASSESSMENT AND PLAN: 
1. Right hip degenerative joint disease (DJD)
Assessment: Patient presents with right hip pain, limited range of motion, and positive resistance testing in the right hip. Physical exam revealed decreased range of motion in the right hip with pain in the groin and internal and external rotation. Resisted right hip flexion caused pain in the right groin region. Motor control was normal in the lower extremities.
Plan: 
- Continue to educate patient on proper posture and body mechanics.
- Provide patient with a handout on low impact exercises to perform.
- Prescribe nsaids as needed to help with pain and discomfort.
- Use of a cane to help offload the right side.
- Consider cortisone injection into the right hip joint to alleviate pain and inflammation.
- Schedule follow-up appointment in 3 months to assess response to treatment and consider repeat injection if necessary.

Follow-up instructions: 
- Return to clinic in 3 months for follow-up appointment.
