Dialogue:
[doctor] patrick allen . date of birth : 7/7/1977 . new patient visit . past medical history includes gerd , anxiety , depression . here for chronic abdominal pain . he had an abdominal ct on 1/23/2020 . impression is a normal ct of the ab- abdomen .
[doctor] hello , are you mr. allen ?
[patient] yes , i am .
[doctor] hi . my name is dr. edwards . nice to meet you .
[patient] nice to meet you .
[doctor] welcome to the gi specialty clinic .
[patient] thank you .
[doctor] did you have any problems finding us ?
[patient] no , i've been here with my sister once before .
[doctor] good . so how can i help you today ? uh , the referral i have is for abdominal pain and diarrhea .
[patient] right . so i've had ... i've been having this pain right here in my stomach , like right around here .
[doctor] so in the area of your mid abdomen , just below the belly button ?
[patient] correct . i've had the pain on and off for about two years . i finally went to the er and a ... a few months ago and they did a ct scan .
[doctor] i saw that .
[patient] yeah . they said they did n't really see anything on the scan .
[doctor] yes , i agree . it looked normal .
[patient] the problem is i'm either constipated or have explosive diarrhea .
[doctor] is the pain there all the time ?
[patient] it's a nagging feeling and it just depends . sometimes it bothers me , sometimes it does n't .
[doctor] has this been the case over the past two years as well ?
[patient] more recently in the past couple months , at least with the constipation and diarrhea .
[doctor] and before that , how are your bowel movements ?
[patient] they were normal .
[doctor] uh , okay . so any blood in your stool ?
[patient] nope .
[doctor] do you feel like you have more constipation or diarrhea ?
[patient] probably more constipation .
[doctor] okay , so when you're constipated , do you not have a bowel movement or is the stool hard ?
[patient] i usually do n't go , but when i do , it's hard .
[doctor] and how often do you have a bowel movement when you are constipated ?
[patient] about three to four times a week . it's like when i need to go to the bathroom , if i can massage it , it feels like it's moving some and i can eventually go .
[doctor] okay . and when you have a bowel movement , does the pain change ?
[patient] yeah , it gets a little better .
[doctor] and are you eating and drinking okay ? any nausea or vomiting , heartburn or indigestion ?
[patient] none of that .
[doctor] okay . so tell me about the diarrhea , how often do you get it ?
[patient] it kinda just depends on what i eat . i think i have a very sensitive stomach . if i eat pasta with a creamy sauce , i'm probably gon na have diarrhea .
[doctor] okay . and it does n't happen for multiple days in a row or is it just one time ?
[patient] it's usually just one time and then it's over .
[doctor] and how's your weight been ? any fluctuation ?
[patient] nice and pretty stable , although i could stand to lose about 25 pounds .
[doctor] okay . and is there any family history of gi issues that you know of ?
[patient] not that i can think of . well , actually my sister does have problems with her stomach too . she has irritable bowel syndrome and that is kind of what i always thought i had even thought i've never been diagnosed with it .
[doctor] okay . and is there any family history of gi cancer or liver disease ?
[patient] nope .
[doctor] have you ever had any surgeries on your abdomen ?
[patient] i've never had any surgery .
[doctor] okay , so your gallbladder , appendix , all those are still intact ?
[patient] yup .
[doctor] and have you ever had a colonoscopy ?
[patient] no . i thought that happen when you turn 50 .
[doctor] well , that's for colon cancer screening , but there are other reasons to have a colonoscopy , like unexplained abdominal pain and changes in bowel habits .
[patient] okay .
[doctor] well , come have a seat here and lay back so i can examine you .
[patient] okay .
[doctor] i'm gon na start by listening to your belly with my steth- stethoscope . and i hear bowel sounds in all four quadrants .
[patient] what does that mean ? is everything okay ?
[doctor] it just means that i can hear little noises in all areas of your belly , which means your bowels are active and working .
[patient] okay , good .
[doctor] so now , i'm going to push on your upper and lower abdomen . let me know if you have any pain .
[patient] it hurts a little when you push right there on the left side , near my belly button .
[doctor] okay . i do feel stool in your lower colon , which would coincide with constipation , but i also feel a slight enlargement of your liver here on the upper right side . have you had any lab work done recently ?
[patient] yes , i have a physical about four months ago and they ... i had blood drawn then .
[doctor] okay . and did your primary care physician say anything about the lab results ?
[patient] he said i had some very slightly elevated liver enzymes , but we would recheck them in about six months .
[doctor] and you remember what enzymes were elevated , alt , ast , alp ?
[patient] he said the alt and the ast were elevated .
[doctor] and do you take any medications , either prescription or over-the-counter ?
[patient] i take crestor and olmesartan daily and then tylenol for occasion- occasional pain .
[doctor] and how frequently do you take the tylenol ?
[patient] hardly ever . maybe once a month .
[doctor] and do you consume alcohol ?
[patient] uh , yes , but only a couple of beers after working in the yard on saturdays .
[doctor] okay . and no previous history of heavy alcohol or drug use ?
[patient] nope .
[doctor] and have you had any recent issues with excessive bruising or bleeding ?
[patient] nope .
[doctor] and how about any issues with your ankles or feet swelling ?
[patient] no .
[doctor] okay . i'm gon na take a look at your eyes and skin . i do n't see any jaundice .
[patient] what would cause that ?
[doctor] issues with your liver . let me take a quick listen to your heart and lungs .
[patient] okay .
[doctor] lungs are clear , bilateral heart sounds are normal , no murmurs , gallops , or rubs noted .
[patient] that's good .
[doctor] yes . the rest of your physical exam is normal other than what seems to be an increased stool burden in your colon and a slight hepatomegaly .
[patient] what's that ?
[doctor] increase stool burden means that there's a lot of stool sitting in your colon .
[patient] and that's the constipation , right ? but what about the other thing ?
[doctor] the hepatomegaly means the liver is enlarged .
[patient] but you said mine was slightly enlarged ?
[doctor] correct .
[patient] so what does that mean ?
[doctor] well , let's talk about what we found and then some possible next steps if you're in agreement .
[patient] okay .
[doctor] so as i said , the hepatomegaly means your liver is enlarged .
[patient] could that be why my stomach is hurting and i'm having issues with the constipation and diarrhea ?
[doctor] no , i think you're constipated and have occasional bouts of diarrhea because of certain foods you eat . and we can get you started right away on a fiber supplement that should help with that .
[patient] so what about my liver ? why is it enlarged ?
[doctor] well , there are many reasons why people can have an elevated liver enzymes and also enlarged liver . some possible causes are certain medications that can be toxic to liver , alcohol abuse , fatty liver disease , hepatitis , cirrhosis , and other liver diseases like wilson's disease .
[patient] so what do i need to do ?
[doctor] well , i think since it's been about four months since your blood work was done , we should check your liver enzymes in addition to a few other labs .
[patient] okay . and then what ?
[doctor] we will get those drawn today and then depending upon the results you may need an ultrasound of your liver . i think we need to talk about your medications too .
[patient] which medications ?
[doctor] crestor , how long have you been taking that ?
[patient] about 18 months .
[doctor] okay . well , crestor is one of the medications that can cause liver toxicity so it may be a good idea to discuss other alternatives .
[patient] should i talk to my primary care or can you change it ?
[doctor] i would recommend calling your primary care and discuss that with him since he follows you for your blood pressure and cholesterol .
[patient] okay . i'll call him this afternoon .
[doctor] great . i also think we should go ahead and get you scheduled for a liver ultrasound . if your blood work looks good , then we can always cancel that .
[patient] okay . when do you think i'll be able to get the ultrasound done ?
[doctor] hopefully , within the next two weeks . you will receive a call from the radiology scheduling this afternoon to get it set up .
[patient] okay . and then what happens ?
[doctor] when i get the results from the test , i will contact you . and depending upon what we find , we'll come up with our next steps .
[patient] and when should i see you again ?
[doctor] uh , let's schedule an appointment when you check out to return in four weeks . we'll discuss how you're doing with the fiber supplement and your constipation and review test results to determine if we need to do further testing on your liver .
[patient] okay . is there anything else i can do to help with these issues ?
[doctor] definitely refrain from drinking any alcohol , increase your water intake to at least 48 ounces a day in addition to taking the fiber supplement to help with your constipation . and be mindful of eating foods that you were sensitive to so you can avoid the bouts of diarrhea .
[patient] okay . and i'll talk to my primary care about my crestor .
[doctor] excellent . and do you have any other questions for me ?
[patient] i do n't think so .
[doctor] great . so remember when you check out the front desk , schedule follow-up appointment with me for four weeks and then go to the lab to get your blood work drawn .
[patient] okay . sounds good .
[doctor] and expect a call from radiology scheduling about setting up your ultrasound .
[patient] all right . thanks , dr. edwards .
[doctor] thank you , mr. allen .
label: sub
Note_1:
SUBJECTIVE
CHIEF COMPLAINT
Abdominal pain, constipation, and diarrhea.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS
The patient is a pleasant [age]-year-old male who presents to the GI clinic for evaluation of abdominal pain, constipation, and diarrhea. He reports that his symptoms began approximately 2 years ago. The patient states that his pain is located in the midabdomen, just below the umbilicus. It is described as a nagging feeling that comes and goes. The patient notes that his constipation is worse in the morning and resolves with defecation. He denies any associated hematochezia or melena. The patient also reports episodes of diarrhea, which typically occurs after consuming pasta with creamy sauce. His diarrhea is described as occurring one time per episode and lasting for several hours. The patient denies any changes in his bowel habits during pregnancy. He reports no history of surgery on his abdomen. He denies any family history of gastrointestinal (GI) issues. The patient's mother has irritable bowel syndrome (IBS). He also denies any personal history of heavy alcohol or drug use. The patient takes Crestor and Olmesartan daily and occasionally takes Tylenol for headaches.

[patient] nope .
[doctor] do you feel like you have more constipation or diarrhea ?
[patient] probably more constipation .
[doctor] okay , so when you're constipated , do you not have a bowel movement or is the stool hard ?
[patient] i usually do n't go , but when i do , it's hard .
[doctor] and how often do you have a bowel movement when you are constipated ?
[patient] about three to four times a week . it's like when i need to go to the bathroom , if i can massage it , it feels like it's moving some and i can eventually go .
[doctor] okay . and when you have a bowel movement , does the pain change ?
[patient] yeah , it gets a little better .
[doctor] and are you eating and drinking okay ? any nausea or vomiting , heartburn or indigestion ?
[patient] none of that .
[doctor] okay . so tell me about the diarrhea , how often do you get it ?
[patient] it kinda just depends on what i eat . i think i have a very sensitive stomach . if i eat pasta with a creamy sauce , i'm probably gon na have diarrhea .
[doctor] okay . and it does n't happen for multiple days in a row or is it just one time ?
[patient] it's usually just one time and then it's over .
[doctor] and how's your weight been ? any fluctuation ?
[patient] nice and pretty stable , although i could stand to lose about 25 pounds .
[doctor] okay . and is there any family history of gi issues that you know of ?
[patient] not that i can think of . well , actually my sister does have problems with her stomach too . she has irritable bowel syndrome and that is kind of what i always thought i had even thought i've never been diagnosed with it .
[doctor] okay . and is there any family history of gi cancer or liver disease ?
[patient] nope .
[doctor] have you ever had any surgeries on your abdomen ?
[patient] i've never had any surgery .
[doctor] okay , so your gallbladder , appendix , all those are still intact ?
[patient] yup .
[doctor] and have you ever had a colonoscopy ?
[patient] no . i thought that happen when you turn 50 .
[doctor] well , that's for colon cancer screening , but there are other reasons to have a colonoscopy , like unexplained abdominal pain and changes in bowel habits .
[patient] okay .
[doctor] well , come have a seat here and lay back so i can examine you .
[patient] okay .
[doctor] i'm gon na start by listening to your belly with my steth- stethoscope . and i hear bowel sounds in all four quadrants .
[patient] what does that mean ? is everything okay ?
[doctor] it just means that i can hear little noises in all areas of your belly , which means your bowels are active and working .
[patient] okay , good .
[doctor] so now , i'm going to push on your upper and lower abdomen . let me know if you have any pain .
[patient] it hurts a little when you push right there on the left side , near my belly button .
[doctor] okay . i do feel stool in your lower colon , which would coincide with constipation , but i also feel a slight enlargement of your liver here on the upper right side . have you had any lab work done recently ?
[patient] yes , i have a physical about four months ago and they ... i had blood drawn then .
[doctor] okay . and did your primary care physician say anything about the lab results ?
[patient] he said i had some very slightly elevated liver enzymes , but we would recheck them in about six months .
[doctor] and you remember what enzymes were elevated , alt , ast , alp ?
[patient] he said the alt and the ast were elevated .
[doctor] and do you take any medications , either prescription or over-the-counter ?
[patient] i take crestor and olmesartan daily and then tylenol for occasion- occasional pain .
[doctor] and how frequently do you take the tylenol ?
[patient] hardly ever . maybe once a month .
[doctor] and do you consume alcohol ?
[patient] uh , yes , but only a couple of beers after working in the yard on saturdays .
[doctor] okay . and no previous history of heavy alcohol or drug use ?
[patient] nope .
[doctor] and have you had any recent issues with excessive bruising or bleeding ?
[patient] nope .
[doctor] and how about any issues with your ankles or feet swelling ?
[patient] no .
[doctor] okay . i'm gon na take a look at your eyes and skin . i do n't see any jaundice .
[patient] what would cause that ?
[doctor] issues with your liver . let me take a quick listen to your heart and lungs .
[patient] okay .
[doctor] lungs are clear , bilateral heart sounds are normal , no murmurs , gallops , or rubs noted .
[patient] that's good .
[doctor] yes . the rest of your physical exam is normal other than what seems to be an increased stool burden in your colon and a slight hepatomegaly .
[patient] what's that ?
[doctor] increase stool burden means that there's a lot of stool sitting in your colon .
[patient] and that's the constipation , right ? but what about the other thing ?
[doctor] the hepatomegaly means the liver is enlarged .
[patient] but you said mine was slightly enlarged ?
[doctor] correct .
[patient] so what does that mean ?
[doctor] well , let's talk about what we found and then some possible next steps if you're in agreement .
[patient] okay .
[doctor] so as i said , the hepatomegaly means your liver is enlarged .
[patient] could that be why my stomach is hurting and i'm having issues with the constipation and diarrhea ?

[patient] so what about my liver ? why is it enlarged ?
[doctor] well , there are many reasons why people can have an elevated liver enzymes and also enlarged liver . some possible causes are certain medications that can be toxic to liver , alcohol abuse , fatty liver disease , hepatitis , cirrhosis , and other liver diseases like wilson's disease .
[patient] so what do i need to do ?
[doctor] well , i think since it's been about four months since your blood work was done , we should check your liver enzymes in addition to a few other labs .
[patient] okay . and then what ?
[doctor] we will get those drawn today and then depending upon the results you may need an ultrasound of your liver . i think we need to talk about your medications too .
[patient] which medications ?
[doctor] crestor , how long have you been taking that ?
[patient] about 18 months .
[doctor] okay . well , crestor is one of the medications that can cause liver toxicity so it may be a good idea to discuss other alternatives .
[patient] should i talk to my primary care or can you change it ?
[doctor] i would recommend calling your primary care and discuss that with him since he follows you for your blood pressure and cholesterol .
[patient] okay . i'll call him this afternoon .
[doctor] great . i also think we should go ahead and get you scheduled for a liver ultrasound . if your blood work looks good , then we can always cancel that .
[patient] okay . when do you think i'll be able to get the ultrasound done ?
[doctor] hopefully , within the next two weeks . you will receive a call from the radiology scheduling this afternoon to get it set up .
[patient] okay . and then what happens ?
[doctor] when i get the results from the test , i will contact you . and depending upon what we find , we'll come up with our next steps .
[patient] and when should i see you again ?

[patient] okay . is there anything else i can do to help with these issues ?

[patient] okay . and i'll talk to my primary care about my crestor .
[doctor] excellent . and do you have any other questions for me ?
[patient] i do n't think so .

[patient] okay . sounds good .
[doctor] and expect a call from radiology scheduling about setting up your ultrasound .
[patient] all right . thanks , dr. edwards .
[doctor] thank you , mr. allen .
label: ap
Note_1:
ASSESSMENT AND PLAN: 
1. Chronic Abdominal Pain 
Assessment: The patient presents with chronic abdominal pain, constipation, and occasional diarrhea. He has a history of GERD, anxiety, and depression. His abdominal CT scan on ___ showed no acute findings.
Plan: 
- Will obtain laboratory studies including LFTs, CBC, and chemistry panel. 
- Will order a fiber supplement to help with his constipation. 

2. Liver Enlargement 
Assessment: The patient has a slightly enlarged liver on physical exam. He has a history of elevated liver enzymes. 
Plan: 
- Will obtain laboratory studies including LFTs, CBC, and chemistry panel. 
- If the lab results show elevated liver enzymes, will consider alternative medications for hypertension and hyperlipidemia. Recommend to discuss with primary care provider. 
- Will schedule an ultrasound of the liver. 
- Will follow up with the patient in 4 weeks to review test results and determine further management. 
Follow-up instructions: 
- Return to clinic in 4 weeks to review test results and determine further management.
Note_2:
ASSESSMENT AND PLAN:

1. Constipation and Diarrhea
Assessment: The patient presents with a history of intermittent constipation and diarrhea, which appears to be related to his diet. He has tried several different types of fiber supplements without success. He also reports that his symptoms improve when he massages his abdomen. His physical examination reveals bowel sounds in all four quadrants, suggesting that his bowels are active and working. However, he has a slightly enlarged liver on physical exam, which could contribute to his constipation and diarrhea.
Plan:
- Will obtain a liver ultrasound to assess for any underlying liver pathology.
- Recommend increasing water intake to at least 48 ounces per day and taking a fiber supplement to help with constipation.
- Advise the patient to be mindful of eating foods that he is sensitive to and avoid foods that trigger diarrhea.
- Schedule follow-up appointment with the GI specialist in 4 weeks.

2. Elevated Liver Enzymes and Mild hepatomegaly
Assessment: The patient has a history of elevated liver enzymes and mild transaminitis, which suggests that he may have liver dysfunction. His Crestor dosage may be contributing to this condition.
Plan:
- Will obtain repeat liver function tests (LFTs) to monitor his liver function.
- Discuss alternative treatments for high cholesterol with the patient's primary care provider.
- Schedule follow-up appointment with the GI specialist in 4 weeks.
Note_3:
ASSESSMENT AND PLAN: 
1. Chronic abdominal pain, constipation, diarrhea, elevated liver enzymes, and hepatomegaly 
Assessment: The patient presents with chronic abdominal pain, constipation, diarrhea, and elevated liver enzymes. He has a history of IBS and his symptoms are consistent with IBS flare. His constipation and diarrhea are likely related to certain foods he eats. His liver enzymes and hepatomegaly are concerning for underlying liver disease. Differential diagnosis includes autoimmune hepatitis, viral hepatitis, and NAFLD. 
Plan: 
- Will obtain CBC, LFTs, AMA, ANTI-smooth muscle antibody, HCV Ab, HBV surface Ag, IgM, and anti-microsoma antibody. 
- Will perform liver ultrasound. 
- Will counsel the patient to stop drinking alcohol and reduce his intake of processed foods. 
- Will start the patient on fiber supplement and loperamide for diarrhea. 
- Will consult with GI service regarding management of IBS and potential liver biopsy. 
- Will refer the patient to nutritionist for education on healthy eating. 
Follow-up instructions: 
- Return to clinic in 4 weeks for follow-up and discussion of test results.

Note_1:
ASSESSMENT AND PLAN: 
1. Kidney Stone 
Assessment: Patient presents with right back pain, right sided hematuria, and right flank tenderness. CT scan revealed a 5mm stone in the proximal right ureter. No signs of hydronephrosis. Urinalysis and urine culture pending. 
Plan: 
- Will obtain BMP and UA/UCx to evaluate renal function and rule out infection. 
- Prescribed Ibuprofen 800mg Q6H PRN for pain relief. 
- Instructed patient to increase fluid intake to facilitate passage of the stone. 
- Will follow up in 1-2 weeks to assess response to treatment. If symptoms persist, may consider lithotripsy.
Note_2:
ASSESSMENT AND PLAN: 
1. Right sided renal colic secondary to staghorn calculus 
Assessment: Patient presents with right sided back pain, nausea, and vomiting after Easter egg hunt. Physical exam reveals mild pain and tenderness to palpation of the abdomen. CT scan revealed a stone measuring 0.5 cm in size in the proximal right ureter. No signs of hydronephrosis. 
Plan: 
- Will obtain BMP, UA, and Urine Culture. 
- Recommend pushing fluids to aid in passage of stone. 
- Prescribing Ibuprofen 800mg Q4hr PRN for pain. 
- Providing strainer to monitor for stone passage. 
2. Nausea and vomiting
Assessment: Patient reports feeling slightly nauseous. 
Plan: 
- Recommend antiemetics as needed. 
Follow-up instructions: 
- Return to clinic in 1-2 weeks for follow-up.
Note_3:
ASSESSMENT AND PLAN: 
1. Kidney stone 
Assessment: Patient presents with right sided back pain, blood in urine, and nausea. CT scan shows a stone measuring 5mm in the proximal right ureter. There is no hydronephrosis. 
Plan: 
- Prescribed ibuprofen 800mg Q6h PRN for pain. 
- Provide a strainer for patients to strain their urine to monitor for passage of the stone. 
- Ordered BMP, UA, and UCx. 
- Will follow up in 1-2 weeks. If symptoms persist, may consider lithotripsy.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN: 
1. Scalp Psoriasis 
Assessment: Diffuse, patchy, scaling erythema on the scalp, likely due to psoriasis. No joint pain, fever, or weight loss. 
Plan: 
- Will start clobetasol 0.05% solution TWICE DAILY to the affected areas of the scalp. 
- Continue using T-gel shampoo. 
- Follow-up in 3 months or sooner if symptoms worsen.
Note_2:
ASSESSMENT AND PLAN: 
1. Scalp psoriasis 
Assessment: Demarcated scaly erythematous plaques on the back of the skull, likely due to scalp psoriasis. Differential diagnosis includes seborrheic dermatitis, eczema, ringworm, or tinea capitis. No history of joint pain, fever, or weight loss. No known family history of psoriasis. 
Plan: 
- Will start clobetasol 0.05% solution TWICE DAILY on affected areas of the scalp. 
- Continue using t-gel shampoo. 
Follow-up instructions: 
- Return to clinic in 3 months or sooner if symptoms worsen.
Note_3:
ASSESSMENT AND PLAN:

Plan:

- Continue to use T- Gel Shampoo. 
- Follow up in 3 months or sooner if symptoms worsen.

The patient reports waking up with shortness of breath, which resolves upon returning home. He reports coughing up approximately three to four cups of blood per day for the past three weeks. He also reports bruising and bleeding from his teeth and gums. He denies any recent travel history, dental problems, or changes in bowel movements. His hemoglobin A1C was elevated at 7.7%.

The patient's physical exam reveals no jugular venous distension, carotid bruits, or signs of meningeal irritation. His lung exam revealed bilateral rhonchi and decreased breath sounds on the right side. His heart exam revealed two over successolic ejection murmurs. His abdominal exam and extemity exam were benign.

The patient reports that his symptoms began approximately a couple of weeks ago. He notes that he wakes up with shortness of breath, which resolves upon returning home. However, he experiences recurrent shortness of breath throughout the day. He also reports coughing up blood, which he estimates is about three to four cups per day. The patient states that the blood is bright red and thick. He denies any coughing up blood prior to this episode. Additionally, the patient reports no swelling in his legs or calves. He denies any recent travel history. He is currently taking Metformin for diabetes, and his blood sugar levels have been running somewhat high, ranging from 200 to 300 mg/dL. His blood sugar levels have been higher in the mornings (around 150 mg/dL) and lower after meals (around 200 mg/dL). The patient also reports that his blood pressure has been running somewhat low, ranging from 90/60 mmHg to 120/70 mmHg. He takes Norvasc for hypertension, but keeps it on some days due to the low blood pressure.

She states that she has been taking her lisinopril as prescribed, but sometimes forgets due to being busy on the weekends. She denies any changes in urination frequency or increased thirst. She rates her headache as a 7 out of 10 when it first starts, which improves to a 4 or 5 after taking Tylenol. She notes that her headaches are unlike her typical migraines, which occur only once a year or every other year. She denies any congestion, cough, runny nose, or sore throat associated with her headache. Note_2:
SUBJECTIVE 
CHIEF COMPLAINT 
Headache. 
HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS 
The patient is a pleasant 37-year-old female who presents to the clinic today for evaluation of headache. She reports recently experiencing frequent headaches, which have become progressively worse over the past several months. The headaches are described as constant, pressing, and severe. They are located primarily in her forehead and temples. The patient denies any associated symptoms such as photophobia, phonophobia, or nausea. She also denies any recent changes in vision or hearing.

The patient reports a history of hypertension and diabetes. She takes lisinopril 20 mg PO Qday for hypertension and metformin 500 mg PO BID for diabetes. However, she admits to occasionally forgetting to take her medications, particularly on weekends when she is busier. She denies any difficulty urinating or increased thirst.

The patient also reports a history of allergies, which typically occur in the spring season. She experiences nasal congestion, sneezing, and ocular discharge. She denies any current symptoms of allergies.

On examination, the patient has soft tappable pulses bilaterally. There is no palpable carotid bruit. The patient has full range of motion in her cervical spine without any tenderness. There is no facial swelling or erythema. There is no tenderness to percussion over the maxilla or zygoma. The patient has moderate tenderness to percussion over the mastoid process.

The patient denies any previous episodes of headaches similar to her current symptoms. She reports occasional migraines, which occur approximately once a year or once every two years. These migraines are characterized by throbbing pain and nausea.

When tapping on her forehead, she feels a little tenderness, and when tapping on her cheekbones, she experiences a little bit more tenderness. If she presses on her neck, she feels a little tenderness.

label: ap
Note_1:
ASSESSMENT AND PLAN: 
1. Chest pain 
Assessment: The patient presents with chest pain, likely due to unstable angina given her history of diabetes and suspected high blood pressure. She denies any shortness of breath, sweating, clamminess, or radiation of pain. Her ECG shows no signs of a heart attack. Differential diagnosis includes costochondritis or musculoskeletal pain. Plan: 
- Referral to cardiology for further evaluation. 
- Start aspirin 81 mg Qday. 
- Prescribe Nitroglycerin (if pain persists while walking). 
2. Diabetes 
Assessment: The patient has type 2 diabetes, currently stable. Her HbA1C is 7%. She reports difficulty adhering to her diet and exercise regimen. Plan: 
- Continue metformin 500mg BID. 
- Order repeat HbA1C. 
- Encourage healthy diet and exercise. 
3. Hypertension 
Assessment: The patient has hypertension, although her blood pressure records are scattered across different clinicians. Plan: 
- Start hydrochlorothiazide 12.5mg Qday. 
- Instruct the patient to measure her blood pressure daily in the morning using a blood pressure cuff and record her findings in Epic MyChart. 
4. Leg swelling 
Assessment: The patient has bilateral leg swelling, likely due to venous insufficiency. Plan: 
- Recommend compression stockings. 
Follow-up instructions: 
- Return to clinic in 2 weeks for follow-up.
Note_2:
ASSESSMENT AND PLAN: 
1. Chest pain 
Assessment: Unstable angina, with possible coronary artery disease. 
Plan: 
- Will refer to cardiology. 
- Start aspirin 81 mg Qday. 
- Give NTG 0.4mg SL x3 doses every 5 min. If still painful after 3 doses, instruct her to go to the hospital immediately. 
2. Diabetes 
Assessment: Well controlled. 
Plan: 
- Continue metformin 500mg BID. 
- Order HbA1C today. 
- Refer to ophthalmologist for eye exam for diabetic retinopathy. 
3. Hypertension 
Assessment: Trending towards hypertension. 
Plan: 
- Start hydrochlorothiazide 25mg Qday. 
- Instruct her to use a blood pressure cuff at home and enter the readings into Epic MyChart. 
- Monitor blood pressure daily in the morning when she wakes up. 
- Refer to cardiology.
Note_3:
ASSESSMENT AND PLAN: 
1. Chest pain 
Assessment: Patient presents with chest pain, which is likely due to unstable angina given her history of diabetes, hypertension, and family history of heart disease. EKG today showed no signs of a heart attack. Cardiac risk factors include diabetes, hypertension, and hyperlipidemia. Differential diagnosis includes PE, ACS, pulmonary embolism, and pneumonia.
Plan: 
- Will refer to cardiology with stress test. 
- Started aspirin 81 mg Qday. 
- Prescribed Nitroglycerin PRN for chest pain. 
2. Diabetes 
Assessment: Patient has type 2 diabetes with poorly controlled HbA1C of 7%. She reports difficulty adhering to diet and exercise due to her chest pain. 
Plan: 
- Continue Metformin 500mg BID. 
- Order HbA1C today. 
- Schedule follow-up in 2 weeks. 
3. Hypertension 
Assessment: Patient has a history of hypertension, although her blood pressure is currently within normal limits. 
Plan: 
- Start hydrochlorothiazide 12.5mg Qday. 
- Instruct patient to measure blood pressure at home using a cuff and enter results in Epic MyChart. 
4. Leg swelling 
Assessment: Patient has moderate bilateral nonpitting edema, suggestive of chronic venous insufficiency. 
Plan: 
- Encourage leg elevation and compression stockings. 
Follow-up instructions: 
- Return to clinic in 2 weeks for follow-up and management of these issues.

Note_1:
ASSESSMENT AND PLAN:
1. Shortness of breath 
Assessment: Exacerbation of CHF, possibly due to poor compliance with diuretics.
Plan:
- Increase Lasix dosage from 20mg to 60mg Qday for the next 4 days.
- Weight check every day.
- Use Albuterol and Atrovent inhalers prn.
2. Diabetes mellitus type 2
Assessment: Hemoglobin A1C level is likely elevated due to poor compliance with metformin.
Plan:
- Order hemoglobin A1C test.
- Adjust metformin regimen accordingly.
3. Back pain
Assessment: Musculoskeletal pain in the lower back.
Plan:
- Start Naprosyn and Flexeril.
- Physical therapy if needed.
4. Nausea and vomiting
Assessment: Patient reports feeling crazy and nauseous. Differential diagnosis includes anxiety vs. migraine.
Plan:
- Check blood pressure and urine analysis.
- Consider prescribing anti-emetics or anti-anxiety medications.
5. Hypertension
Assessment: Blood pressure is stable.
Plan: Continue lisinopril 20mg Qday.

Follow-up instructions:
- Return to clinic in 2 days to follow up on shortness of breath and diabetes control.
Note_2:
ASSESSMENT AND PLAN:

1. Shortness of breath due to CHF exacerbation
Assessment: Exam reveals crackles, wheezing, and JVD, consistent with CHF exacerbation. Patient reports increased SOB with lying flat. She denies fever, cough, or sputum production. CXR was unremarkable. Differential diagnosis includes PNA, asthma, or bronchitis. However, symptoms suggest CHF exacerbation.
Plan:
- Increase Lasix from 20mg to 60mg QDay.
- Instruct patient to monitor her weight daily.
- Prescribe Albuterol and Atrovent inhalers.
- Order Hemoglobin A1C.
- Follow up in 2 days to assess response to treatment.

2. Diabetes mellitus type 2
Assessment: Patient's last HgbA1c is 7.5%, suspecting poor blood sugar control.
Plan:
- Order Hemoglobin A1C.
- Adjust Metformin dosage if needed.

3. Back pain
Assessment: Exam reveals tenderness in lower back. No midline tenderness. Good reflexes. Differential diagnosis includes musculoskeletal pain vs. radiculopathy.
Plan:
- Start Naprosyn and Flexeril.
- Provide exercises to help patient get off the couch.
- If pain persists, consider starting physical therapy.

Follow-up instructions:
- Return to clinic in 2 days to follow up on progress.

Nonhealing foot ulcer. 
HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS 
The patient is a pleasant female who presents to the clinic today for evaluation of her nonhealing foot ulcer. She was treated with Keflex on and off and last time was 5 months ago, but the ulcer has not improved. The patient denies any pain, but states she has decreased sensation in her foot due to neuropathy. She also reports increased drainage from the ulcer recently and fatigue. Her A1C is 10. She has been eating out and not following her primary care provider's recommendations regarding her diet.

label: ap
Note_1:
ASSESSMENT AND PLAN:

1. Diabetic Foot Ulcer 
Assessment: The patient has a nonhealing diabetic foot ulcer, likely due to her uncontrolled type 2 diabetes. She has had multiple courses of antibiotics without improvement. X-ray shows no evidence of osteomyelitis.
Plan: 
- Order ABIs to evaluate blood supply. 
- Debridement of the wound in the office. 
- Prescribe Collagenase ointment and instruct patient to apply once daily to the wound and cover with a sterile dressing. 
- Provide surgical shoe to reduce pressure on the ulcer. 
- Follow up in 2 weeks for further evaluation and possible additional debridement.
Note_2:
ASSESSMENT AND PLAN: 
1. Diabetic foot ulcer 
Assessment: One by two centimeter two inch circular wound on the dorsal aspect of the lateral right foot, with minimal granulation tissue, no surrounding erythema or cellulitis, no fluid collection, no necrosis, no odor, no bony exposure. X-ray shows no evidence of osteomyelitis. 
Plan: 
- Order ABI/ankle brachial index to determine blood supply. 
- Debridement of the ulcer. 
- Prescribe collagenase ointment to apply to the wound once a day and cover it with a sterile dressing. 
- Provide a surgical shoe to wear. 
- Follow up in 2 weeks. 
- Consider additional debridement as needed.
Note_3:
ASSESSMENT AND PLAN: 
1. Diabetic foot ulcer 
Assessment: Nonhealing, 1x2cm circular wound on the dorsal aspect of the lateral right foot, with yellow slough, minimal granulation tissue, no surrounding erythema or cellulitis, no fluid collection, no odor, no bony exposure, and no necrosis. X-ray of the right foot shows no evidence of osteomyelitis. 
Plan: 
- Will perform ABI/ankle brachial index to determine blood supply. 
- Will perform debridement of the ulcer. 
- Will apply Collagenase ointment to the wound daily and cover it with a sterile dressing. 
- Will obtain a surgical shoe to reduce pressure on the area. 
- Will follow up in 2 weeks for repeat evaluation and possible further debridement.

2. Type 2 diabetes 
Assessment: Patient reports poorly controlled blood sugar levels despite treatment with metformin and insulin. Last A1C was about 10%. 
Plan: 
- Continue current treatment regimen. 
- Refer to endocrinology for further management.

1. Chest Pain 
Assessment: The patient has chest pain that comes and goes, and it is associated with arm pain and neck pain. He has a history of hypertension and diabetes. A cardiac evaluation should be performed to rule out a heart attack.

Plan:

Note_2:
ASSESSMENT AND PLAN: 
1. Chest pain 
Assessment: The patient has chest pain that comes and goes, starts yesterday, and is associated with elbow pain and neck pain. It is unlikely to be due to musculoskeletal pain given its sudden onset and association with elbow and neck pain. EKG and cardiac enzymes may be ordered to rule out acute coronary syndrome (ACS). Nitroglycerine may be administered to help relieve pain. 
Plan: 
- Order EKG and cardiac enzymes. 
- Administer nitrogylcerine. 
2. Hypertension 
Assessment: The patient's blood pressure is elevated today. Norvasc 5mg Qday may be continued. 
Plan: 
- Continue Norvasc 5mg Qday. 
3. Diabetes 
Assessment: The patient has diabetes and has not been checking his blood sugar levels. A1C level was 7.2% last time. Metformin 500mg Qday may be continued. 
Plan: 
- Check fasting blood sugar. 
- Continue Metformin 500mg Qday. 
4. Elbow pain 
Assessment: The patient has elbow pain that comes and goes and is associated with chest pain and neck pain. Musculoskeletal pain is less likely given its sudden onset and association with chest and neck pain. An X-ray or MRI may be ordered to evaluate for bone fracture or soft tissue injury. 
Plan: 
- Order X-ray or MRI. 
- Administer analgesics as needed.
Note_3:
ASSESSMENT AND PLAN: 
1. Right elbow pain 
Assessment: Patient presents with right elbow pain, which has been present for several days. It is aching in nature and extends up to the neck. The exact mechanism of injury is unknown, but it may be related to sleeping on it wrong or lifting heavy objects. No significant change in pain with Motrin. Differential diagnosis includes musculoskeletal injury versus neurological disorder such as cervical radiculopathy. 
Plan: 
- Will obtain X-ray of the right elbow to rule out fracture or degenerative changes. 
- Will perform a thorough physical examination to evaluate for neurologic deficits. 
- If X-ray is negative, will consider referral to orthopedics for further evaluation. 
2. Chest pain 
Assessment: Patient reports chest pain that occurs intermittently and is associated with his right elbow pain. He describes it as aching in nature and comes and goes. The exact mechanism of injury is unknown, but it may be related to coronary artery disease or pulmonary embolism. 
Plan: 
- Obtain ECG to evaluate for signs of cardiac ischemia. 
- Administer Aspirin and Nitroglycerin PRN for possible angina. 
- Will consult Cardiology if ECG reveals evidence of acute coronary syndrome. 
3. Diabetes mellitus type 2 
Assessment: Patient has poorly controlled diabetes mellitus type 2, with A1C >7%. He reports occasional episodes of hyperglycemia, but denies frequent hypoglycemia. 
Plan: 
- Will obtain fingerstick glucose level and hemoglobin A1c to evaluate for adequacy of current treatment regimen. 
- Will increase Metformin dosage to 500mg BID if fasting glucose is above 140mg/dL. 
- Will refer patient to Endocrine Consultant for further management of his diabetes. 
4. Hypertension 
Assessment: Patient has well-controlled hypertension, with systolic blood pressure ranging from 120-160mmHg. 
Plan: 
- Continue Norvasc 2.5mg Qday. 
5. Hyperlipidemia 
Assessment: Patient has hyperlipidemia, with LDL >100mg/dL. 
Plan: 
- Start Atorvastatin 40mg Qday. 
Follow-up instructions: 
- Return to clinic in 1 week for follow-up of his right elbow pain, chest pain, and diabetes mellitus type 2.

label: ap
Note_1:
ASSESSMENT AND PLAN: 
1. Right knee injury, likely medial collateral ligament (MCL) sprain 
Assessment: The patient presented with right knee pain, swelling, and limited range of motion, suggesting MCL sprain. Physical exam revealed pain on palpation on the inside of the knee, as well as pain on flexion and extension of the knee. McMurray's test was negative. Plan: 
- Will place patient in a straight leg brace. 
- Prescribe mobic for pain relief and to reduce swelling. 
- Order MRI of the right knee to confirm diagnosis and evaluate for any other damage to the knee. 
2. Diabetes 
Assessment: Patient reports history of diabetes, which is currently well controlled. However, she forgot to check her blood sugar levels regularly. Plan: 
- Recommend frequent glucose monitoring. 
- Obtain hemoglobin A1C level to assess for adequate control of diabetes. 
3. Hypothyroidism 
Assessment: Patient reports history of hypothyroidism, which is currently well controlled. Plan: 
- Continue levothyroxine Sodium 50mcg Qday.
Note_2:
ASSESSMENT AND PLAN: 

1. Right knee injury
Assessment: The patient presented with a right knee injury, likely a torn or injured medial collateral ligament (MCL) based on her symptoms of popping and swelling. She also has limited range of motion and pain on both flexion and extension of the knee.
Plan:
- Will place the patient in a straight leg brace.
- Prescribe Mobic for pain relief and to reduce inflammation.
- Recommend icing the knee once an hour for 15 minutes.
- Order an MRI to confirm the diagnosis and rule out any other damage to the knee.

2. Diabetes
Assessment: The patient has type II diabetes and is managing it fairly well, although she forgot to check her blood sugar levels occasionally.
Plan:
- Recommend getting a recheck of the hemoglobin A1C level.
- Provide a refill for the Metformin 500mg tablet.
Note_3:
ASSESSMENT AND PLAN: 
1. Right knee injury, suspected MCL tear
Assessment: The patient presented with right knee pain, swelling, and limited range of motion. She reported a pop and pain immediately following the injury. Physical exam revealed pain on palpation on the inside of the knee, as well as pain on the outside of the knee with bending and extending. MCMurray's test was negative. Differential diagnosis includes MCL tear, patellar tendinitis, quadriceps tendinitis, osteochondritis dissecans, or chondromalacia patellae. Plan: 
- Will place patient in a straight leg brace. 
- Will prescribe Mobic 15mg Qday PRN pain. 
- Will refer patient for MRI to confirm diagnosis and evaluate for other injuries. 
2. Diabetes
Assessment: Patient reports being compliant with her diet, but forgetful about checking her blood sugar levels. Her HbA1C level will be checked to assess diabetes control. Plan: 
- Will obtain a repeat HbA1C level. 
- Will continue current dosage of Metformin (500mg) for now.

Establishing care for a history of DCIS.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS
The patient is a pleasant 75-year-old female who presents for establishment of care for a history of DCIS. Her most recent mammogram was performed in January 2021 and was normal. The patient reports a history of non-HTLV+, ER/PR+, invasive ductal carcinoma of the right breast (stage 0). She had a normal colonoscopy in 2018, and her last menstrual period was approximately 30 years ago. She denies any history of miscarriage or termination. She takes CoQ10, vitamin D, vitamin C, fish oil, and elderberry fruit. She is post-menopausal and has not taken HRT. She has a history of back and knee pain, which are age-related. She was recently diagnosed with hypercholesterolemia and is working on exercising and cutting back on fatty foods to try to control it without medication.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN: 
1. Ductal Carcinoma In Situ (DCIS) 
Assessment: Patient has a history of DCIS, grade II ER/PR positive, invasive ductal carcinoma of the right breast. She underwent lumpectomy on January 20th, 2020, which removed the 8mm tumor and margins were negative. The pathology confirmed DCIS. 
Plan: 
- Will continue to monitor the patient closely and perform routine breast exams. 
- Recommend annual mammography starting in April of 2022. 

2. High Cholesterol 
Assessment: Patient has a history of high cholesterol. Her current LDL level is unknown. 
Plan: 
- Continue to work with the patient's primary care provider to manage her cholesterol. 
- Consider statin therapy if necessary. 

3. Back Pain 
Assessment: Patient reports age-related back pain. 
Plan: 
- Encourage regular exercise and stretching. 
- Consider physical therapy if needed. 

4. Joint Pain 
Assessment: Patient reports joint pain. 
Plan: 
- Encourage regular exercise and stretching. 
- Consider physical therapy if needed. 

5. Family History of Non-Hodgkin's Lymphoma and Prostate Cancer 
Assessment: Patient has a family history of non-Hodgkin's lymphoma and prostate cancer. 
Plan: 
- Discuss risk factors and early detection strategies with the patient. 
- Refer the patient to genetic counseling if desired. 

Follow-up instructions: 
- Follow up with Dr. ___ in 1 year, or sooner if any changes occur. 
- Have a mammogram in April of 2022 prior to returning to the office.

- Continue to monitor the patient's condition closely. 
- Recommend annual mammography starting in April 2022.

- Continue to monitor the patient's lipid profile and adjust treatment as needed. 
3. Back Pain and Joint Pain 
Assessment: The patient has age-related back and joint pain, which is being managed with conservative treatments such as exercise and physical therapy. 
Plan: 
- Continue to manage the patient's pain with conservative treatments.

- Continue to monitor the patient's blood pressure and adjust treatment as needed.

Assessment: The patient is allergic to penicillin.
Plan:
- Avoid using penicillin in the patient's treatment regimen.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN:
1. Right medial unicompartmental arthroplasty, 6 weeks post-operative:
Assessment: The patient is recovering well from her surgery. She has some residual numbness on the lateral aspect of her right leg, which should improve over time. She is ambulating without assistance and has full range of motion in her right knee. Her x-rays show stable implant placement.
Plan:
- Continue physical therapy to work on strength, range of motion, and endurance.
- Follow up in 6 weeks to assess progress and provide additional instructions.
2. Occupational health issues:
Assessment: The patient is unable to return to work due to her current condition. However, she is being asked to return to work in a sedentary role.
Plan:
- Will write a letter to excuse her for another 6 weeks.
- Recommend avoiding heavy lifting (>5lbs) and prolonged sitting or standing (>30min).
- Discussion regarding returning to work will be deferred to the next follow-up appointment.

- Follow up in 6 weeks for a telemedicine visit to assess progress.

Note_1:
ASSESSMENT AND PLAN: 
1. Shortness of breath 
Assessment: The patient presents with dyspnea on exertion, likely due to COPD. She has a history of smoking and depression. Pulmonary function tests suggest possible asthma or COPD. Chest X-ray shows flattened diaphragm consistent with COPD. Physical exam reveals mild wheezes in all lung fields. 
Plan: 
- Diagnosis: COPD 
- Treatment: 
-- Combivent (ipratropium bromide) inhalation solution Q6H 
-- Albuterol inhalation solution PRN 
-- Prednisone taper pack 
2. Depression
Assessment: The patient reports her depression is stable. She continues to take Effexor. 
Plan: 
- Continue Effexor. 
3. Chronic back pain 
Assessment: The patient reports chronic back pain. She continues to take Gabapentin. 
Plan: 
- Continue Gabapentin. 
Follow-up instructions: 
- Return to clinic in 1 month for follow-up.

She has a history of depression, which may contribute to her symptoms. Her pulmonary function tests suggest COPD. X-ray shows flattened diaphragm, which is consistent with COPD. Physical exam reveals mild wheezes in all lung fields. 
Plan: 
- Diagnosis: COPD 
- Treatment: 
-- Combivent (two puffs twice daily) 
-- Albuterol (two puffs as needed) 
-- Prednisone taper pack 
2. Depression: 
Assessment: The patient has a history of depression, which is currently stable. 
Plan: 
- Continue Effexor. 
3. Chronic back pain: 
Assessment: The patient has a history of chronic back pain, which is currently controlled with Gabapentin. 
Plan: 
- Continue Gabapentin. 
Follow-up instructions: 
- The patient will follow up with Dr. ___ in 6 weeks.
Note_3:
ASSESSMENT AND PLAN:
1. Chronic Obstructive Pulmonary Disease (COPD)
Assessment: Patient presents with shortness of breath, wheezes in all lung fields, and imaging studies showing flattened diaphragm, consistent with COPD. Physical exam reveals mild wheezes in all lung fields. Diagnosis was confirmed by pulmonary function tests and x-ray.
Plan:
- Start Combivent 2 puffs BID.
- Start Albuterol PRN for shortness of breath.
- Prescribed Prednisone Taper Pack.
- Continue Effexor for depression.
- Encourage yoga for depression and back pain.
- Continue Neurontin for back pain.
2. Depression
Assessment: Patient reports feeling depressed with periods of extreme low mood. She continues to take Effexor.
Plan:
- No changes to current medication regimen.
3. Back Pain
Assessment: Patient reports chronic back pain. Imaging studies revealed flattened diaphragm, suggestive of COPD.
Plan:
- Continue Neurontin for back pain.
Follow-up instructions:
- Return to clinic in 6 weeks or sooner if symptoms worsen.

Second opinion regarding the index finger on the right hand.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS
The patient is a 50-year-old male who presents for a second opinion regarding the index finger on the right hand. He sustained a hyperextension injury of that finger during a motor vehicle accident in March of this year. The patient was offered an injection of the A1 polyregion, but declined due to a previous reaction to dexamethasone, which caused his heart to race. The patient underwent MRI on 4/24/2021, which showed just focal soft tissue swelling over the right index MCp joint, partial-thickness tear of the right FDS, and fluid consistent with tenosynovitis around the FDP and FDS tendons. Radial and ulnar collateral ligaments of the index MCp joint were intact, and the extension of the MP joint capsuled. Extensor tendons were also deemed intact. An X-ray of the right hand today shows no bony abnormalities, joint congruency throughout all lesser digits on the right hand, no soft tissue shadows of concern, no arthritis. The patient reports that he has been experiencing pain in his right index finger since the accident. He denies any history of diabetes or rheumatoid arthritis. He takes only a blood pressure pill and experiences itching with methylprednisolone.

[doctor] at that practice , an mri was obtained on 4/24/2021 , which showed just focal soft tissue swelling over the right index mcp joint , partial-thickness tear of the right fds , and fluid consistent with tenosynovitis around the fdp and fds tendons . radial and ulnar collateral ligaments of the index mcp joint were intact , as the mcp joint capsule . extensor tendons also deemed intact .
[doctor] his x-rays , four views of the right hand today , show no bony abnormalities , joint congruency throughout all lesser digits on the right hand , no soft tissue shadows of concern , no arthritis . hi , how are you , mr . gutierrez ?
[patient] i'm good , how about you ?
[doctor] well , how can i help you today ?
[patient] so i was a passenger in , uh , a car that was rear-ended , and we were hit multiple times . i felt two bumps , which slung me forward and caused me to stretch out my right index finger .
[doctor] so hitting the car in front of you all made that finger go backwards ?
[patient] um , i do n't really know . i just felt , like , it felt like i laid on my finger , and so , i felt like it went back , and it's been hurting since about march . and it's been like that ever , ever since the wreck happened . so i , and i ca n't make a fist , but sometimes the pain's unbearable . and , like , even driving hurts .
[doctor] okay , so this was march of this year , so maybe about three months ago ?
[patient] yeah , and it's still swollen . so i was seeing , uh , an orthopedist , and they sent me to an occupational therapist . and i've been doing therapy with them , and then they sent me to go back and get an mri . so i went and got the mri . uh , then they told me that the mri came back , and it said i had a tear in my finger , but he was n't gon na give me an injection , because the injection was going to make the tear worse .
[doctor] mm-hmm .
[patient] and then , after he got the mri , he said that i have , uh , a tear in my finger , and that he did n't wan na do surgery , but he would do an injection . then i'm thinking that you told me you would n't do an injection in there , and then the oper- , occupational therapy says it's because of the tear . and then , they do n't want me to keep rubbing the thing , and doing things with my hand . so i feel like i'm not getting medical care , really .
[doctor] yeah , i see that .
[patient] so i came to see if you could do anything for this hand , because i am right-handed , and i kinda need that hand .
[doctor] what do you do for a living ?
[patient] uh , i'm an x-ray tech .
[doctor] well , um , so do you have any diabetes or rheumatoid arthritis ?
[patient] nope .
[doctor] uh , do you take any chronic medications of su- , significance ?
[patient] uh , i do take a blood pressure pill , and that's it .
[doctor] okay , and it looks like you suffer from itching with the methylprednisolone ?
[patient] uh , that's correct .
[doctor] all right , well , i'm gon na scoot up closer and just take a quick look at your hand . all right , so , lean over here . all right , so on this exam today , we have a very pleasant , cooperative , healthy male , no distress . his heart rate is regular rate , rhythm , 2+ radial pulse , no swelling or bruise , bruising in the palm over the volar surface of his index finger , normal creases , slightly diminished over the pip of the index finger compared to the middle finger .
[doctor] his index finger rests in a 10-degree pip-flexed , uh , position . all right , is that uncomfortable to correct that , and is it uncomfortable now here ?
[patient] yeah , uh , when you push on it , yeah .
[doctor] all right , how about here ?
[patient] um , there , it's not .
[doctor] okay , not as bad ?
[patient] yeah , it feels , uh , a little numb .
[doctor] gotcha , all right . bend , bend the tip of this finger . bend it as hard as you can . keep bending . keep bending . all right , straighten it out . all right , and now , bend it for me as best you can .
[patient] my goodness . it feels like it's , it's tearing in there .
[doctor] okay , okay . well , bend the tip of this finger , and bend it as hard as you can . keep bending . all right , straighten that out , and now , bend it for me as best you can . all right , good . now , bend that finger , and i'm going to pull , put it down like this . and then bend that finger for me . okay , sorry , can you bend it for me ? all right . now , make a fist . great , so relax the finger . all right , so just keep it , keep , when i bend the finger , we're just going to bend that finger where it meets the hand . is that okay there ?
[patient] ow , .
[doctor] okay , okay . so all the hurt , it seems , is stretching , because you have n't been doing this for so long . so , you know what i mean ? so , um , you're going to have to start really doing that .
[patient] well , i've tried . i even bought myself a splint .
[doctor] well , but a splint does n't help move you . it actually immobilizes you .
[patient] okay . i thought it would straighten it out .
[doctor] no , no . so , so you really need to start bending the finger right here for me , as hard as you can , and keep going , going . all right , so , so you're okay . all right , so i would say the following , that there is a partial tear in one of the two flexor tendons . there is the fdp and the fds , and the fds is the least important of the two . so the mri shows that it's the fds , the flexor digitorum superficialis , which is the least important of the two .
[patient] okay .
[doctor] uh , now , there's two halves of it . so it's a partial tear of one half of a whole tendon . that's not that important , and the other one is just fine .
[patient] so the good one is good ?
[doctor] yes , correct . so the one that goes all the way to the tip is good .
[patient] okay , good .
[doctor] yeah , so you know , i think what you have got so much scar tissue and inflammation around the fds tendon blocking excursion of these other tendons , that they ca n't get through to the pulley .
[patient] okay , all right .
[doctor] so what i would recommend what we try is a cortisone injection , and i would avoid the dexamethasone , because i saw you have a little reaction to that . but we could use the betamethasone , which is a celestone .
[patient] i've gotten another , uh , methylprednisolone , and that itched me like crazy .
[doctor] did it ? yeah , this one is water-soluble , and i think it's fairly low toxicity , but high benefit , and i think decreasing the pain will encourage you to move that finger .
[patient] all right , we'll give it a try .
[doctor] good . so , you do the shot , and it's going to take about three to five days before it starts feeling better . and then probably over the next couple of weeks , it'll start feeling even better .
[patient] perfect .
[doctor] all right , so take advantage of that . you've got ta start moving the finger . you're not going to tear anything or break a bone , uh , because your intensors , extensors are intact . but your collateral ligaments are intact , so you've got a stiff , sore finger . i'm going to try to help as much as i can with this soreness part , and then you have to do all the stiff part .
[patient] the lady in occupational therapy tried some maneuvers to straighten the finger out , but it even hurt after i left . the whole thing just swelled up .
[doctor] hmm . okay , so it was injured , and you had scar tissue . and then , you had post-traumatic inflammation . and so , this will help some with all of that . it's not going to make it to where your finger is like , , my finger does n't hurt at all , but it will make it to where at least tolerable , to where you can make some gains . and we actually might need to repeat this as well .
[patient] will i be able to drive ? i drove myself here today , so ...
[doctor] yeah , it may feel a little weird , but it's totally safe for you to drive .
[patient] okay , good .
[doctor] so for mr . gutierrez , just put that he has a post-traumatic rather severe stenosing tenosynovitis of his right index finger , and the plan is steroid injection today , do a trigger injection , but i'm using a cc of betamethasone . so , mr . gutierrez , do you have , um , therapy scheduled or set up ?
[patient] uh , not at the moment .
[doctor] all right , well , i mean , you know that you need to move that finger , and i think to the degree that they can help you do that . so i want you to move that finger , finger , but i think it would be , uh , beneficial for you to have an accountability , um , so at least you know to check in with them once a week with somebody .
[patient] um , okay . that's kinda why i'm here , for you to tell me what needs to be done , you know ?
[doctor] yeah , so i'll write you out , um , an outpatient prescription . i think if you go back to the same people where you were before , i'm hoping that after this injection , you're going to be able to do a whole lot more with them . so let's do outpatient once a week for six weeks , um , and then full active and passive range of motion is the goal with no restrictions .
[patient] all right , sounds like a plan .
[doctor] all right , well , i will have the nurse set up the injection procedure , and we'll , and i'll be back shortly .
[patient] thanks , doc .
[doctor] right trigger finger injection template . attempted to inject one cc of celestone with f- , a half a cc of lidocaine . however , the patient had a dramatic and violent painful reaction to the introduction of the needle , with contortions of the hand , and with dangerously withdrawing the hand with concerns for secondary needle stick . needle was withdrawn . the patient was counseled as to the importance of attempting to get some therapeutic steroid in the flexor tendon sheath . we attempted a second time for a similar injection using the same technique with one cc of celestone and half a cc of lidocaine . a small parma- , uh , palmar vein bled a scant amount , which was cleaned up and band-aid applied . reassured on multiple occasions that no harm was done to his finger . recommended icing in it this evening , and taking ibuprofen .
label: ap
Note_1:
ASSESSMENT AND PLAN:

1. Right index finger stenosing tenosynovitis
Assessment: Partial tear of FDS tendon, moderate stenosis, and mild edema on MRI. Patient reports significant pain and limited function.
Plan:
- Corticosteroid injection (betamethasone) today.
- Outpatient follow-up in 6 weeks for further evaluation and treatment.
- Range of motion exercises and physical therapy.

2. Hypertension
Assessment: The patient takes lisinopril for hypertension.
Plan:
- Continue lisinopril.

Follow-up instructions:
- Follow up with Dr. ___ in 6 weeks for further evaluation and treatment.
- Start range of motion exercises and physical therapy.
- Wear a splint at night to prevent contractures.
- Avoid heavy lifting and repetitive activities.
Note_2:
ASSESSMENT AND PLAN:
1. Post-traumatic rather severe stenosing tenosynovitis of the right index finger
Assessment: The patient has a history of a hyperextension injury of the right index finger, followed by MRI showing partial-thickness tear of the right FDS tendon, fluid consistent with tenosynovitis around the FDP and FDS tendons, and radial and ulnar collateral ligaments of the index MCp joint were intact, as the MPJ capsule. He has been seen at Point May Orthopedics largely by the physical therapy staff and a PR, PA at that institution. On examination, the patient has a slight decrease in pinch strength in the right IP pads, and a positive FDS test with minimal discomfort.
Plan:
- Will perform a trigger finger injection of the right index finger with betamethasone.
- Recommend starting physical therapy twice per week for 6 weeks, with a focus on active and passive range of motion exercises without restrictions.
- Follow up in  weeks to assess progress.
Note_3:
ASSESSMENT AND PLAN:
1. Partial tears of the flexor tendons of the right index finger, specifically the flexor digitorum profundus (FDP) and flexor digitorum superficialis (FDS) tendons. The FDS is the least important of the two tendons.
Assessment: Examination revealed a partially torn flexor tendon of the right index finger, with moderate pain and limited mobility. MRI confirmed the findings.
Plan:
- Will perform a cortisone injection into the affected area to reduce pain and inflammation.
- Patient will follow up with hand surgery team in 6 weeks for further evaluation and treatment.
- Patient will continue with occupational therapy to improve finger movement and strength.
- Patient will return to clinic for review of progress and adjustment of treatment plan as needed.

2. Post-traumatic inflammation of the right index finger.
Assessment: Examination revealed post-traumatic inflammation of the right index finger without significant changes in the joint.
Plan:
- Will provide a trigger injection of betamethasone to reduce pain and inflammation.
- Patient will follow up with hand surgery team in 6 weeks for further evaluation and treatment.
- Patient will continue with occupational therapy to improve finger movement and strength.
- Patient will return to clinic for review of progress and adjustment of treatment plan as needed.

3. Scarring and stiffness of the right index finger.
Assessment: Examination revealed scarring and stiffness of the right index finger due to prior injuries and inflammation.
Plan:
- Will provide hand exercises and stretches to improve finger movement and strength.
- Patient will follow up with hand surgery team in 6 weeks for further evaluation and treatment.
- Patient will continue with occupational therapy to improve finger movement and strength.
- Patient will return to clinic for review of progress and adjustment of treatment plan as needed.

4. Driver safety.
Assessment: Patient reported that he drives himself to appointments despite having difficulty turning the steering wheel and accelerating.
Plan:
- Will advise patient to refrain from driving until his symptoms improve significantly.
- If necessary, will refer patient to a driver rehabilitation program to assess his ability to safely operate a vehicle.

Dialogue:
[doctor] tyler nelson , date of birth : 3 , 6 , 1949 , mrn , 385729 . he is here today for ongoing management of rheumatoid arthritis . last time he was here , he received a steroid injection in his right knee . hello mr. nelson , how are you ?
[patient] um , about the same as last time . my knee is still swollen .
[doctor] that was your right knee , correct ? i take it the injection did n't help ?
[patient] it did , maybe for a couple of weeks .
[doctor] that's it ? and is it still painful ?
[patient] yeah , it's pretty painful , and now the whole leg is getting swollen .
[doctor] okay , what would you say your pain level is ?
[patient] i mean , right now it's about a 3 or so , but , typically on a normal day it's around 6 .
[doctor] okay , and its been swollen like that for how long now ?
[patient] since i was last here a couple weeks after that . so about , maybe two months now .
[doctor] okay , but before it was just the knee ?
[patient] yeah , the whole thing was n't swollen like this , but i tried to wear compression socks a lot of the time , but it has n't been helping .
[doctor] okay , okay , so that has n't been working for you ?
[patient] i mean , it helps to some degree , but it's still swollen , especially around the knee .
[doctor] hmm . has it been keeping you from doing things during the day ?
[patient] well , i slowed down a little bit , and i found a few things too fast . but when it really hurts , is when i've been sitting for a while , and then i have to try and get up . i'm so stiff getting up i have to use a cane to get my bearings . i mean , after a little bit , it loosens up , but that first getting up is real difficult .
[doctor] yeah , i can see , that makes sense . have you been taking your medication regularly ? your on xeljanz right ?
[patient] yeah , the xr , i think its , uhm , 11 milligrams a day ? yeah , but i'm taking it everyday , and i'm also taking celebrex which i started maybe 2 months ago .
[doctor] yes , the 200mgs daily . how's that working for you ?
[patient] pretty good , up until it started swelling again .
[doctor] okay , well come sit over here , and if you could take of your socks and shoes , and we'll take a look at your knee . and just to let you know , i have a service now that writes my note about the visit , so you'll hear me call things out and describe what i see fully .
[patient] okay , gotcha .
[doctor] right , so let's check your leg . can you straighten it , and does it hurt ?
[patient] yeah , when i try to straighten it all the way it does .
[doctor] okay , range of motion slightly diminished . i'm going to press here , okay ? and how about here , hmm , i see some pitting around the knee and ankle . normal capillary refill in the toes . does any of this area hurt ?
[patient] um , just kinda sore , like an old bruise ?
[doctor] so , i can feel that the knee is hot , and that means there's something going on , like some inflammation . so we can give you another steroid injection for that . i also want to get an x-ray of that knee , so we can see where all the swelling is coming from .
[patient] yeah . let's do it . sounds go to me .
[doctor] okay , and did we set up physical therapy for you last time you were here ?
[patient] yeah , that was some years ago , but that was the other knee .
[doctor] okay . so i think we'll set that up for you now . we'll also do an x-ray on that knee . i can send you for a physical therapy , and if nothing is helping , then we really might need to get a surgery consult to see what we can do with that knee .
[patient] okay , sounds like a plan .
[doctor] all right , so for today we'll go ahead and we'll give you the steroid shot . i'll try to see if i can get a little bit of fluid out before i do give you the injection . there might be no fluid , but i'll see if i can get anything out regardless .
[patient] okay . and that's a procedure you're going to do right now ?
[doctor] yep . once we're done talking here , and as far as the edema in your legs , uh , we'll take an x-ray to look for the cause , but there is a lot you can do as well . the compression socks are a good start . um , and also , do you eat a lot of salt ?
[patient] i mean , um , i mean i love my salty snacks .
[doctor] okay . well , salt does have a tendency to make your body hold on to water , reducing your salt intake could help with some of the swelling . you can also prop your feet up any time you get a chance , especially at night . and have you talked to your private care doctor about this at all ?
[patient] no , i figured i would just come here first .
[doctor] okay . so i think , try some of those things out first , and if it does n't help , definitely make an appointment with them , also , as you know , xeljanz is a high-risk medication , so we need to check your cmp levels every couple of months . so this time your levels are good , but do make sure to make an appointment for the blood work for next time .
[patient] all right . i can do that . thank you so much doc .
[doctor] yes , of course . well let me go ahead and get supplies and we'll get to work on your knee .
[doctor] fluid aspiration and steroid injection procedure . the risks , benefits , and alternatives were explained . the risks of steroid injection were explained , including , but not limited to : hypopigmentation , soft tissue atrophy , tendon ruptures , and transient hypoglycemia among others . verbal consent was attained . the right knee was , uh , um , accessed through the lateral approach with 3 milliliters of initially clear fluid , then bloo- blood tinged fluid . then the right knee was prepped in a standard-fashion . the right knee was injected with 80 milligrams of triamcinolone , and one milliliter of lidocaine . the procedure was tolerated well , with no complications . post-procedure instructions were given . patient will follow up with his pcp . thank you .

SUBJECTIVE
CHIEF COMPLAINT
RHEUMATOID ARTHRITIS.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS
The patient is a pleasant [age]-year-old male who presents for ongoing management of rheumatoid arthritis. He reports that his right knee is still swollen, despite receiving a steroid injection in his right knee last time he was seen. The swelling began approximately 2 months ago. His pain level is currently 3 out of 10, although it is usually 6 out of 10. He also reports that his entire leg is swollen, not just the knee.

He denies any changes in his hearing or vision. He continues to take Xeljanz (11 mg per day) and Celebrex (200 mg per day). He states that these medications have been helpful, but they have not completely resolved his symptoms. He also reports using compression stockings, but they have not helped significantly.

Rheumatoid arthritis, left knee pain and swelling.

The patient reports that his pain level is currently 3 out of 10, and he has had swelling for approximately 2 months. He states that his swelling began after he started taking Xeljanz and Celebrex. He denies any new fevers, chills, or shortness of breath. The patient continues to take Xeljanz 11mg QD and Celebrex 200mg QD. He has not experienced any side effects from these medications.

He states that his pain level is usually around 6, but it has been as low as 3 recently. The patient denies any recent changes in his hearing or vision. He denies any recent falls. He denies any recent fevers, chills, or night sweats. He denies any recent weight loss or change in appetite. He denies any recent hematuria or hemoptysis. He denies any recent melena or hematochezia.

The patient's review of systems is otherwise unremarkable.

label: ap
Note_1:
ASSESSMENT AND PLAN:
1. Rheumatoid Arthritis
Assessment: Patient reports persistent swelling and pain in right knee, despite previous steroid injection. He also reports increased swelling in both legs. Physical exam shows range of motion slightly diminished, pitting edema around knee and ankle, and warmth indicating inflammation. X-ray of right knee is recommended.
Plan:
- Will perform ultrasound guided fluid aspiration and steroid injection of right knee.
- Will obtain CMP to monitor liver function.
- Will refer patient to physical therapy.
- Will consider surgery consult if conservative treatment fails.
- Encourage patient to reduce salt intake and elevate legs whenever possible.
2. Edema in legs
Assessment: Patient reports edema in both legs, likely due to RA.
Plan:
- Will obtain x-ray of right knee to evaluate cause of edema.
- Will recommend compression stockings and leg elevation.
- Will refer patient to private care doctor for further evaluation and treatment.
Note_2:
ASSESSMENT AND PLAN:
1. Rheumatoid Arthritis
Assessment: Patient presents with persistent swelling, pain, and reduced range of motion in the right knee. X-ray shows evidence of degenerative changes and possible effusion. He has failed conservative treatments such as compression stockings and Celebrex. 
Plan:
- Will obtain X-ray of the right knee to evaluate for bone destruction and joint space narrowing. 
- Will prescribe physical therapy and possibly orthotics. 
- If these measures fail, will consider referral to orthopedics for surgical evaluation. 
2. Edema in lower extremities
Assessment: Patient has bilateral swelling in the lower extremities. Likely due to venous insufficiency and poor circulation. 
Plan: 
- Encourage elevation of the legs. 
- Reduce sodium intake. 
- Consider ACE wrap or compression stockings. 
Follow-up instructions: 
- Follow up with primary care provider (PCP) for further management.
Note_3:
ASSESSMENT AND PLAN: 
1. Rheumatoid Arthritis 
Assessment: The patient presents with worsening pain, swelling, and stiffness in his right knee. He has had previous steroid injections and physical therapy, but these have not provided adequate relief. 
Plan: 
- Will perform fluid aspiration and steroid injection in the right knee. 
- Will order X-ray of the right knee. 
- Will refer the patient to physical therapy. 
- Will recommend lifestyle modifications such as compression stockings, elevating the legs, and reduced salt intake. 
- Will continue current medications including Xeljanz 11mg QD and Celebrex 200mg QD. 
- Will monitor CMP levels every couple of months.

[doctor] uh , mrn49282721 . patient's name is jacqueline miller . use last visit exam where appropriate .
[doctor] hi , how are you doing , jacqueline ?
[patient] i'm pretty . good . how are you ?
[doctor] good as well . so it sounds like we're , um , under good control right now .

Rash on face.

Rash on face.

The patient is a pleasant female who presents for follow-up of her rash on her face. She reports that she has been using a combination of Doxycycline, Elidel, Metrocream, Sulfacetamide Wash, and Cetaphil Cleanser. She states that she began experiencing improvement after switching from twice daily to once daily usage of Doxycycline. However, the rash has not completely cleared. The patient denies any changes in her breathing, chest pain, fevers, dizziness, headaches, or joint pains. She also denies any recent travel, new sexual partners, tick bites, animal exposures, or environmental exposures.
